title: Opening Question
choices: Ultimate reality is conscious Mind or Spirit - not material particles - from which the universe emerges purposefully.
God-talk is meaningful only as ethical metaphor; there is no actual transcendent being.
The concept of God is outdated; only matter and energy exist, and consciousness is merely brain activity.
The divine is an impersonal force or ground of being, not a conscious creator with purposes.
God is a supernatural being who directly intervenes in natural processes and human history.
hint_wrong: The answer emphasizes that God is best understood as primal consciousness - ultimate reality as Mind/Spirit - rather than either a supernatural intervener or mere metaphor.
explanation_right: This captures the view that the God question is fundamentally about whether ultimate reality is conscious Mind rather than unconscious matter.
question_text:
Let us begin by entering the worldview of our skeptical neighbors. Although much of the world remains deeply religious, skepticism is dominant in the United Kingdom, much of Europe, and in many urban centers in the United States. For many, talk of “being religious” seems absurd, problematic, or simply odd. It appears absurd because people are unsure what the word “God” even means, and because the role once played by God in the human imagination has largely been replaced by scientific accounts. It seems problematic because an allegedly good and all-powerful God appears to permit horrendous suffering. And it is seen as odd because religious people appear to engage in strange practices—spending their time “praising” and “worshipping” God. What sort of fragile ego, skeptics ask, requires such constant affirmation?

Turning to the first of these concerns. How do we respond to the question of what we mean by the word “God,” and how this understanding relates to modern science? A large, invisible, intangible person standing outside the material world sounds implausible to many. People do not know what they are meant to imagine—an energy, a spirit, a force? Can it be seen? Where is it located? And how can we decide what it is like? Different religious traditions, of course, offer varying accounts of the ultimate source of the universe.

Faith also has a fraught relationship with science. Some argue that science and religion can be harmonized. Yet in practice many believers across the globe continue to reject evolution. Scripture often attributes natural phenomena to divine action (the flood in Genesis, for example), while science explains weather through entirely different mechanisms. Scripture interprets historical events as the work of God (Cyrus being raised up to topple Babylon in Isaiah), while modern historians appeal to sociological and economic factors. Scripture is filled with miracles, while modern medicine heals through surgery, antibiotics, and technology.

The result is that our skeptical neighbors often see no reason to take religious discourse seriously. They are unsure what believers mean by central claims—such as “God,” let alone “Trinity.” And they wonder how belief in God could possibly help us understand the world in which we live. So, help me out: what should we say to our skeptical neighbors?
answer_text:
GOD

You are right. Many people think of God as a superhero, who controls the weather and determines who will win the various wars that litter human history.  God looks like the muscular bearded figure whose picture is on the roof of the Sistine chapel in Rome, touching Adam, the first human being, with his finger.

However beautiful the Sistine Chapel roof is, it is just completely wrong about God. The best thing to do about that picture is just to obliterate it from our minds altogether. But what should we put in its place?

The real question about God is the question of the ultimate nature of reality. There are a number of possible answers to this question, and ‘God’ is one of them. One answer is the agnostic one – we just don’t know. But that just seems like a lack of curiosity, and a depressing pessimism about the human capacity to understand the universe.

Among other answers there are two main alternative accounts which are in competition. One is materialism – the ultimate nature of reality is that it is a spacetime made up of material particles (atoms or quarks or superstrings, perhaps) or fields of energy, which continually change in accordance with universal ‘laws of nature’. These particles, fields, and laws, have no consciousness, meaning, or purpose. They simply happen to exist, and in time the universe will probably cease to exist, and that is all there is to it.

This is thought by many to be what science shows us. Life on our planet came about by chance. It is a sort of improbable accident. Yet there can be no doubt that consciousness does exist, in animals, including humans; that humans can understand and experience what the universe is like; seem to feel pleasure and pain, happiness and misery; and often act for the sake of future states, purposes which they regard as important.

These, the most obvious and important features of human life, are problems for materialism. There are sophisticated arguments trying to show that they are side-effects, or even illusions, caused by a universe which is basically unconscious, unfeeling, and purposeless. They seem to have arisen by accident, and they are destined to disappear by accident one day.

We may just have to accept this. But if we really thought it through, we might conclude that there is no reason to think, on the materialist view,  that our knowledge is reliable (if it is caused just by the purely physical firing of neurons in the brain),or we might think  that our belief in human freedom is illusory, and that all our purposes are arbitrary and not really consciously chosen. Our view of life would probably become both extremely pessimistic and very depressing.

I believe, having once been a materialist, that it is partly because many people are materialists that serious concern with truth and morality is rare among humans.  But the fact is that we know that consciousness, feelings of pleasure and pain, of value and disvalue, and actions for the sake of a consciously chosen future goal (purposes) do exist in humans. So we know, since we are parts of nature,  that not all the processes of nature are unconscious (‘blind’), purely accidental, and without value.

This raises the main alternative idea about the ultimate nature of reality – namely, that consciousness, feeling, and purposive action, are the ultimate basis of reality. They are responsible for the whole material universe. This is, in its most general sense, philosophical Idealism. There are many sorts of Idealism, and not all of them use the idea of God. But God, if there is one,  is a reality with consciousness and feeling, which has a purpose in creating the universe. God is a creator who knows and understands all things, who distinguishes between value and disvalue, and who is the source of all things in the universe.

Even those who believe there is such a creator have different opinions about how to define God in more detail. But this is a minimal core definition of God. It is a basic way of saying that the ultimate reality is not a physical being. God is the name some give to a reality which is conscious, wise, and blissful. This reality creates a physical universe for a reason. That universe contains finite beings who share these values of consciousness, feeling, and freedom. These values are not accidental, and human lives are not pointless.

The first step in thinking seriously about God is thus not to look for evidence of an invisible  superhuman being outside the universe (Bertrand Russell compared God to an invisible teapot going around the sun). It is to see that the God hypothesis is a serious philosophical theory about what the ultimate reality is like. It is a reality of consciousness, feeling, and purpose, which generates the physical universe. People like me, and in fact most well-known philosophers throughout history, think it is the best theory going.

title: Question Two
choices: Religious diversity proves no religion is true; they are all human projections.
Religious diversity reflects humanity's gradual, culturally-shaped exploration of spiritual reality - all views develop and face problems.
One religion must be wholly true while others are false; we should identify and follow that one.
Only direct mystical experience matters; all doctrinal formulations are misleading.
All religions are equally valid paths to the same truth; differences are superficial.
hint_wrong: The answer suggests religious diversity is natural given how human knowledge develops - through culture, criticism, and gradual refinement.
explanation_right: Religious beliefs, like all beliefs, are shaped by culture and develop through criticism - diversity is expected, not a refutation of truth.
question_text:
– Religious Diversity

We have, then, the following picture: agnosticism is an option, but shows a pessimism about the human capacity to understand the world. Materialism is a more serious metaphysic, but this runs into the problem of consciousness. Therefore the most likely explanation for consciousness is an ultimate consciousness, namely God.

Your proposed definition of God is “a reality with consciousness and feeling, which has a purpose in creating the universe. God is a creator who knows and understands all things, and who is the source of all things in the universe.”

So, we have arrived at a possible hypothesis. As you admit, the details about this cosmic consciousness are a matter of disagreement. Hinduism tends to a pantheism (where the world is identified in some sense of with the consciousness); and the Abrahamic traditions (Christianity, Judaism, and Islam) tends to the view that this consciousness is separated from the rest of creation.

So, let us dig a little deeper. For our skeptical friend, all this religious diversity is very confusing. How do we decide which religion is right? Which account of God is more likely to be true? And why does God allow all these different religions? Is God deliberately making belief difficult?
answer_text:
Human knowledge of reality is not handed to us on a plate. It has to be obtained by experimentation and reflection; it grows through argument and criticism; and it is never final and complete. For instance, Darwin’s account of evolution was discounted by many of the best biologists of his day. Quantum theory was opposed by Albert Einstein, even though he was partly responsible for it. Things are even worse in questions of ethics and politics. The best minds disagree about socialism and capitalism, and about abortion and euthanasia.

Why should religion be any different? Questions about the ultimate nature of reality are going to be very difficult to answer. Until 100 years ago, no one knew that there are galaxies and planets beyond the Milky Way. Before the birth of quantum theory, no one knew that light was both waves and particles, and even today disputes rage about which is primary, or how both can be true at the same time. Dispute and development are part of the human condition, so we should expect them in religion as in most human searches for truth.

Different cultures have different values and histories, and that affects how they think of reality. Each of us is born into a particular culture. Our language and ideas will be taught to us when we are young. Even if we later rebel, we will never escape their influence. Even famous atheists like Nietzsche or Bertrand Russell will speak in the terms of the religious culture in which they were raised.

We all start with beliefs and values we learn from others. We do not look at all the basic beliefs there are, and then decide between them from a neutral position. But many of us, as we grow, begin to find problems with what we have learned. Using knowledge from other sources, we begin to see that our initial beliefs need restating, revising, or even rejecting. So it is never a question of deciding ‘which religion is right’, like choosing cereals in a supermarket. It is a matter of facing up to (or ignoring) specific problems about our existing beliefs that we come up against.

We can see this happening in the Bible. In the earliest parts of the Bible, God is clearly regarded as one of many Gods, ‘a king above all gods’ indeed, but not the only god. God is also often very harsh and punitive, killing people who touch the Ark of the Covenant, even by accident,  or walk on his holy hill. By the time the book of Isaiah was written, there was only one creator God, and though he was ruthless in judgment, he was also a god of mercy and compassion. When Christianity came along, theologians used the philosophies of Plato and Aristotle to speak of God as the most perfect non-physical reality.

These were all developments in the idea of God, influenced by changing knowledge of the world and changing moral beliefs. Such developments continued, and multiplied after the European Reformation and the Enlightenment. At the time I write this, traditional ideas of God, which still have an intellectual background in ancient Greek philosophy,  face challenges to restate or reject them from modern science, greater knowledge of non-European traditions, and more liberal and humane ethical views.

There are religious traditions which do not work with the idea of one personal God. Indian and Chinese traditions do generally believe in a spiritual basis of reality, but often think of the term ‘God’ as too anthropomorphic andof monotheism as leading to an authoritarian, paternalistic, and exclusive view of the spiritual world.  They are often sceptical about there being a moral purpose for the universe,  and think of the hope for personal immortality with God as too self-centred. These are indeed dangers of theism, and those who feel such factors  strongly may be attracted to non-theistic religions. I think that these dangers can be avoided, but they, and similar moral and social considerations, help to  explain why so many different religious views exist. And they suggest that greater interaction between religions may lead to greater understanding of the human condition.

Overall, it  is not realistic to say that we ‘choose’ our beliefs, whether in science, ethics, or religion. What we can do is try to be clear about what our beliefs are, discover the historical and cultural forces that influenced them, find out what problems they now seem to have, and only then make decisions about how best to cope with them. All belief systems change and face problems. In the case of God, it is pretty obvious what they are. In my view, the problems of materialism are much worse, and the problems with God are mostly because people have an idea of God which is out-dated or over-simple or too closely associated with questionable moral views and social practices.  Maybe we need to be more critical of our own beliefs, and more open to see the advantages of others – and that goes for both religious believers and non-believers.

title: Question Three
choices: Faith is blind trust that contradicts reason; the less evidence, the more meritorious.
Faith is merely accepting a philosophical hypothesis with moderate probability.
Faith combines rational reflection with personal experience - it is passionate commitment made in objective uncertainty.
Faith requires absolute certainty and cannot tolerate any doubt or questioning.
Faith is simply following inherited tradition without personal engagement.
hint_wrong: The answer distinguishes between God as philosophical hypothesis and faith as experiential commitment - both reason and experience matter.
explanation_right: Faith is not just hypothesis-acceptance but passionate personal commitment rooted in experience, while still engaging reason.
question_text:
– Being committed to an hypothesis

So, then, standing back, we have the following picture. Theism (a belief in a personal God) is a better hypothesis than materialism because it more effectively explains the mystery of consciousness. Now the nature of this God - the cosmic consciousness - is subject to considerable debate among religious believers. This is not surprising because every area of human knowledge is subject to debate. And like every belief (politics, economics, science), we do not really pick our beliefs, they are given to us by our particular upbringing and culture that we inhabit. It makes sense that we should rationally reflect on our beliefs and modify them as we encounter inconsistencies, insights from other areas, and find more plausible explanations for the complexity of life. This entire argument seems very plausible. However, all this raises two major questions.

It sounds like belief in God is the act of affirming a hypothesis that is tentative, culturally shaped, and in need of endless modification. Contrast this with the Gospel of Matthew. Here we have Jesus give various instructions to the twelve disciples (“proclaim the good news”, “cure the sick” – Matthew 10:7-8) and then explains:

See, I am sending you out like sheep into the midst of wolves; so be wise as serpents and innocent as doves. Beware of them, for they will hand you over to councils and flog you in their synagogues; and you will be dragged before governors and kings because of me, as a testimony to them and the Gentiles. … Brother will betray brother to death, and a father his child, and children will rise against parents and have them put to death; and you will be hated by all because of my name. (Matthew 10:16-22)

People who are willing to be flogged, dragged, betrayed, and hated, don’t sound like they are people who believe in a God hypothesis aware of the cultural limitations of their beliefs. These people are sure.

Later in the Gospel of Matthew, we have the story of epileptic who is suffering and the disappointed father who is puzzled that the disciples could not cure his son. And Jesus explains that the failure of the disciples was due to their lack of faith. Jesus goes on: “For truly I tell you, if you have faith the size of a* mustard seed, you will say to this mountain, ‘Move from here to there”, and it will move; and nothing will be impossible for you.’” (Matthew 17:20). To move a mountain sounds like we need a faith that it is a little more than a sense that the cosmic consciousness hypothesis is plausible.

Perhaps this is all linked with the second related question: so, I am persuaded that materialism is implausible and some religious account makes more sense. But how do you step inside the community of faith? To unpack this a little, I believe that there are other life forms on other planets. But apart from an occasional conversation at a dinner party, this belief does not impact my life at all. It is a speculation that I barely think about most of the time. How, then, do we move from a hypothesis to faith? Why should we make that move? If I might end up getting flogged and dragged, perhaps I would rather stick with a belief in a hypothesis that does not impact my life very much.
answer_text:
That is a very important point. Perhaps I exaggerated when I implied that philosophy leads to God. Many Christians, most notably Karl Barth, have reacted strongly to such claims by saying that God is not a hypothesis, and faith is not a tentative theory. They are right. Faith is a strong moral commitment for which people might be prepared to die. It is like loyalty to and trust in a person, and not very much like accepting a rather abstract and controversial theory about ultimate reality. So I will admit that in my case it was a personal experience of the risen Christ as a dynamic force in my life that led me to become a Christian, and not just being a philosophical Idealist. For many people personal experience is the basis of faith, and does not need philosophical theories to support it. For some people this might be something quite dramatic. For others, belief in God is less dramatic, and might be a general sense of God’s demands for obedience and God’s strengthening presence which is a general background to their experience of life.

No one needs a philosophy degree before they can be people of faith. Indeed, philosophy can confuse people so much with its range of opinions and diversity of views that they may even give up and lose their faith. What faith needs is an experience which is felt to be of a more than material presence that calls for a life-changing response.

If there Is a primal mind which creates the universe, it must presumably do so for a reason. If that mind knows all possible worlds, and knows all possible states which are of intrinsic value or disvalue, a good reason for creating a universe would be to actualize intrinsic values which otherwise would not exist. This universe develops finite minds, and it would be good if they could themselves conceive of intrinsic values which they could pursue.

All this is at a speculative and hypothetical level, and could be just a probabilistic hypothesis – though for me the probability would be quite high. Nevertheless, it would have definite consequences for human experiences. The hypothesis is that the purpose of human existence is to form communities of largely self-shaping and socially interacting personal beings who create new kinds of intrinsic values. But is this hypothesis really a matter of pure speculation, without any basis in experience? In my own case, I had been brought up in a Christian culture, and so was disposed to think in terms of a personal creator, a charismatic religious teacher (Jesus), and a feeling that such things as music and friendship were basic intrinsic values. This would be rather different than being taught that there was no personal God, that Jesus was a mistaken prophet, and that the values of the world were subjective and transient preferences without ultimate value, that would end with death. Perhaps then I might still have become convinced of the priority of consciousness, but would not have associated this with a purposive creation (rather more like Aristotle, before he got squeezed into a Christian mold by Aquinas).

The idea of a personal creator had developed gradually in the ancient Hebrew tradition, and it had been founded on the experiences of exceptional people like the patriarchs and prophets. Speculation had not preceded experience. It largely consisted in reflection on many cumulative experiences of a morally commanding and providentially guiding power. Such critical reflection is important, for experiences can often be very weird or fantastic, and finding a rational organization of them is highly desirable. It will be the case that there will be different organizations of experiences of primal mind in a world of many different cultures and values, and the one that became Judaism formed the idea that God called one community, the Jews, into a special relationship which was to proclaim God’s moral demands and promises to the world. Here was a special vocation, calling for obedience, for hope even in times of disaster, and for an intimate relation of devotion to God. To have faith in this tradition is to accept that vocation, to be obedient to divine law, and to bear witness to the objective reality of truth, beauty, and goodness.

So experience and reflection go hand in hand. God is both a speculative hypothesis, and an experienced reality which commands justice and mercy, empowers action for the sake of goodness, guides many choices in life, and promises moral fulfilment. Historically, such experiences by exceptional individuals come first. Then religious institutions are founded, and ideas such as that of God are formed and develop. Christianity is, historically, an offshoot of Judaism. Jesus experienced God in a particularly intense way, and  experiences by his disciples of his resurrection and of the power of the Spirit at Pentecost, led to the origin of Christian churches.  Meanwhile, in ancient Greece, polytheistic religion was rationalized by philosophers into a form of Idealism. This was in turn used by Christians to give a more personal form of ethical monotheism, for which Jesus Christ is the human image of one creator God.

Idealism as a hypothesis can escape from religion, though even then it is often concerned with fulfilling the purposes for which primal mind, if there is one, presumably originated the universe. But it was born in religion, in communities and institutions following the teachings of those believed to experience spiritual reality in a special way.  Faith in the most general sense was, and is, loyalty to those teachers and experiences, patterning life on them, and maintaining the values and goals they are taken to express. In the Christian case, faith is loyalty.  Obedience, and devotion to the person and teachings of Jesus, and trust in the power, the guidance, and the promise of fulfillment that Jesus gives. That is not just a tentative hypothesis; it is, to paraphrase Kierkegaard, a passionate commitment made in objective uncertainty.

title: Question Four
choices: Evil disproves God's existence; a good omnipotent being would prevent all suffering.
God deliberately creates evil to test human souls and build character.
Evil is illusory; from God's perspective all is perfect.
Much about God is necessary rather than freely chosen - evil possibilities are entangled with goods in the divine nature itself.
Evil exists because Satan rebells against God; the solution is spiritual warfare.
hint_wrong: The answer argues that God's nature includes necessary elements - some evils arise not by divine choice but by necessity, entangled with goods.
explanation_right: The key insight is that God's existence and nature have necessary aspects - destructive possibilities are entangled with creative ones in the divine mind.
question_text:
– The Problem of Evil

This is all very compelling. Rationally, theism compared to materialism makes more sense of consciousness. We arrive at a cosmic consciousness underpinning everything. Given this is a complex claim, there are a variety of different ways of interpreting that consciousness in the different faith traditions. This is not surprising. All human knowledge claims work with a variety of perspectives. However, this is not simply an intellectual hypothesis because what enables a person to find the way to faith is an encounter with God. Reason combines with experience to create a way into faith. Is this a fair summary of your position so far?

However, there is one major difficulty with all this. The theistic claim is that this cosmic consciousness which created this entire universe (or multiverse) is loving. Yet every day, there is horrendous evil. As a human, if I had the power to prevent a child being raped and mutilated, then I would do so. In fact, most humans, I suspect, would do so. But apparently, the entity with the power to prevent a rape just looks on and does not intervene. Why does God behave so much worse than most humans would behave?

Evil as a problem has so many elements. We have the injury that humans inflict on each other; often with the powerful crushing the powerless. Then we have the injury that nature inflicts on sentient life – aging, illness, death, but also the hurricane, tornado, earthquake, and drought. Now granted perhaps human agency is responsible for some of these things because of climate change, but nature creating problems for humans has always been with us. I deliberately say sentient life because a suffering dog or a dolphin or a chimpanzee are all problematic. Anything with a centralized nervous system can suffer. Then we have the lack of divine intervention. The Bible is full of God stepping in and changing history. But when the Jewish people were being led into the gas chambers by the Nazi regime, God was just silent.

There are two more conundrums we need to touch on here. Traditionally, Christians have posited that there is a personal force of evil, surrounded by thousands of demonic minions, that are creating havoc in the world. The narrative also claims that God will ultimately triumph and the Devil and the minions will be vanquished. Why does God allow the devil and demons to create so much suffering? Why doesn’t God bring forward the triumph over the devil and stop all this mayhem? The second conundrum is linked. In the traditional narrative God condemns all those who are skeptical about God’s existence to hell? How can a place of eternal torment and pain be compatible with a God of love?

Our skeptical friends might find faith intriguing, And then they read a newspaper and realize that faith just does not make sense. How can there be a God when there is so much suffering and pain in the world?
answer_text:
This is the hardest problem that a believer in God faces. I  do not think that a Devil solves the problem, because if God created everything, then God created the Devil as well, and why would God do that? Because the problem is so hard, I will have to approach it bit by bit. To give the game away, my response to the problem largely, but not entirely, depends on saying that God cannot help it; there is no alternative. However, I will need to qualify this later. Actually, the main classical  Christian doctrine of God, formulated paradigmatically by Thomas Aquinas, implies that God cannot help it, because it holds that God is both necessary and simple. That is, absolutely everything about God must be just what it is. I do not think this is the case, but I do think that much about God is necessarily the case.

Such a lot is made of saying that God is omnipotent that many people think this means that God can do absolutely anything. But that is not true. There are lots of things God, even the God of traditional Christian theism, cannot do. For the vast number of theologians, God cannot commit suicide or do something wicked, or break a promise. In short, God cannot do anything that contradicts God’s own nature.

Some people may say, ‘Quite so. God is necessarily good; it is not possible for God to do evil. Therefore God could not create a world with evil in it. Evil exists.  Therefore God cannot exist’. But they do not realise that in saying ‘God is necessarily good’ they have said there are many things God cannot do.  For instance, God could not fail to exist or have the general sort of nature God has.

Once you have said that, you are committed to saying that when God creates a universe,  God, being necessary, had no choice about the matter. There is no point in complaining about suffering and evil. The universe, being created by a being whose existence and whose nature and whose actions were all necessary, had to make the universe this way.

This is a great paradox of traditional Christian theism, that God had to create suffering, and yet God is said to be good. How can that be? Well, saying God is omnipotent does not mean that God can do absolutely anything, so saying God is good does not mean that God only creates good things. ‘God is omnipotent’ can mean that God can do anything compatible with God’s nature. ‘God is good’ can mean, for example, that God is perfect wisdom and beauty, that God’s creation must be for the sake of final supreme goodness, and perhaps that creatures will ultimately share in God’s perfection. So God’s creation is truly for the sake of final overwhelming goodness, yet God is unable to prevent much suffering and evil on the way to such a goal. So appeal to the view that God’s existence and nature, and therefore all God’s acts, are necessary solves the problem of how a good God can create a universe like this.

Why should God’s existence be thought of as necessary? Basically, because we do not want to revert to the idea that the world just exists by accident, or comes into being out of nothing, and without any reason.

If we believe in God, we think that the cosmos originates from a primal consciousness. Consciousness is not empty. It must have content. In the case of human consciousness, that content starts with data we have been taught or observed through the senses. Then we can extend those data in creative ways. But primal mind has no data outside itself (there is nothing outside itself). The contents of consciousness, generally speaking,  are thoughts, so there must be thoughts in the primal mind, which do not derive from elsewhere, which are intrinsic to the nature of that mind.

How many thoughts there are, and what their nature is, humans cannot hope to know. But they must include thoughts of our universe, for in creating the cosmos, the primal mind, which I will call God, has a purpose which is the thought, the possibility, the goal of its existence, a present idea of a future state. It must also include the means to that goal. If it did not, there could be no guarantee that God’s purpose would be achieved.

The goodness and badness of mental contents  is not freely chosen by God. Pain, for example, is  bad in every possible world, and pleasure is good in every possible world. These possibilities will necessarily exist in the mind of God. God does not choose them either. So many properties of God are necessary, including God’s existence, knowledge of many possibles, good and bad, the power to actualise at least some of them, and the existence of values and disvalues; they could not be otherwise.

It may seem that God would necessarily choose the best possible states for itself, so God in that respect would necessarily be supremely good. In fact, God would be perfect – meaning that God is supremely worth-while just for God’s own sake. But maybe God could create beings other than itself. It may even seem that to do so would be a good thing, so good that some sort of creation would be necessary. Perhaps a perfect being would generate and relate to other beings. If creativity and personal relationship are good, some such creation too could be a necessary property of God.

Within Christianity, this view is actually accepted by many theologians, who think that God (the Origin or ‘Father’) necessarily and changelessly generates a perfect being to love (the Generated or ‘Son’), and this, together with a third being (the Relation, or ‘Spirit’), completes a divine society of love. This, they say, is the Trinity. I have  a slightly different view of the Trinity, as I think that there are too many problems with saying that there are three supreme beings which are all God, yet there is only one God. But at least the view accepts that God necessarily generates (even if it is called ‘begetting’ or ‘spirating’ rather than ‘creating’) and relates to others. So this traditionally orthodox Christian view entails that some acts of divine generation are not freely chosen, but are necessary.

There should therefore be  no problem with saying that God necessarily creates some world containing finite persons, and indeed this very world in which we live. Such finite persons could come to be united to the creator and share in the divine nature in an appropriate way. If this was indeed the goal of creation, the idea of that goal would have to exist in God, as would some idea of how finite minds could come into being and achieve that goal. In this way the content of God’s consciousness would have to include the idea of one or more possible worlds which would make the goal achievable. Such an idea could not derive from anywhere but God itself, and it would not be an idea which just happens to exist, though it might not have done. It would be a necessary consequence of God’s perfection, as creative and loving (personally relating to others). Thus God’s nature does not just happen to be the way it is, for no particular reason. God’s nature, properties, and acts, are necessarily what they are, and could not have been otherwise.

How is all this related to the problem of evil? It actually goes a long way to solving the problem of how a perfect God could create a universe containing so much suffering and apparent wastefulness. For it establishes that much about God, perhaps everything, is necessarily what it is. Much of the content of the primal Consciousness is necessary. God’s desire for a community of loving persons is necessary, for it is part of the unoriginated content of God’s mind, which cannot come into being, and is therefore necessarily what it is. God’s creation of a cosmos in which such persons exist is necessary, for it is a consequence of God’s perfection, which includes creativity and love.  God’s actions to fulfil his purpose for the cosmos are necessary, for they are conditions of God’s purpose being achieved. And the possibility of suffering and disaster  is necessary, for such ideas are necessary complements of the ideas of happiness and good fortune, and therefore necessary possibilities in the mind of God.

If something is necessary, there is simply no alternative, and no-one, not even God, can be blamed for it. We do not know exactly what things are necessary for God. So it would be very reasonable to say that many features of creation, and creation itself, just could not be different. Those could well include the origin of the cosmos in violent and catastrophic events like the Big Bang, the formation of the planets by destructive collisions of spatial debris, the battles for survival in animal evolution, or the final dissolution of the cosmos by the inescapable working of the law of cosmic entropy.

The problem of natural disasters is made to seem much worse because we think of God as a well-meaning person who just cannot prevent them happening, though he tries his best. We need to discard this picture, and think instead of a changeless, eternal, and necessary source of all being, of all elements, good and bad, that are immutably set in the divine nature.

If that is true, we could not speak of God as totally loving, in the sense that God always shields finite minds from harm. That would be an over-sentimental and anthropomorphic picture of God. Yet we could speak of God as loving, meaning that God creates a universe which brings into being finite minds with whom God desires and will bring about communities of loving relationships. Yet how that can be done may be conditioned by necessary elements of the divine nature which, because they are necessary, cannot be negated. An understanding of God’s necessity is thus an important part of seeing how a loving God can create a world containing horrendous evil. We may still want to see why these destructive possibilities get to be actualised in our universe,  but the important first step is to understand that they are rooted in the primal consciousness, and their possibility cannot be eliminated. For the classical Christian tradition (formulated by Aquinas, Calvin, and Luther, for example), this is expressed in the idea of predestination, that God decrees everything that happens, good and bad. Evil is seen as necessary. If you can accept this, it is a good explanation of how suffering and disaster can exist even in a universe which is intended to realise great goods. Whether or not it is sufficient, remains to be seen.

title: Question Five
choices: God freely chose to limit divine power, making evil inevitable.
Divine freedom is meaningless since God exists outside time.
God has no freedom at all - everything is predetermined by divine necessity.
God is absolutely free and could have created any possible world, including one with no suffering.
God is necessary in some respects (existing, being good) but free in others (how to create, how to respond).
hint_wrong: The answer navigates between total necessity and total freedom - God is necessary in some ways, free in others.
explanation_right: This preserves both God's essential nature and genuine creative freedom - necessary in existence and goodness, free in particular creative choices.
question_text:
– Divine choice and freedom

Let me just check that I am getting all this. The fundamental claim for Christians is that this world is not an accident; it is a result of purpose. To bring about this universe, the primal consciousness (I like that) – from the Latin primus meaning first – had no choice but to bring about the universe. Now why exactly? Because (and here we listen to our theologian friends who are social trinitarians) God desires more opportunities for loving relationships in the universe. So, God necessarily creates – had no choice but to create. And the method of creation is also in a sense determined – a big bang and natural selection. So, if we want a universe where we exist, then God had no choice but to allow this universe of suffering to emerge.

Is this right?

Now let us just stay here a little longer. First, I am beginning to feel a little sorry for God. Your account of God makes it sound that God has no choices at all. Humans have choices; we have free will. But God on your account does not sound free? And then second, it does sound odd to say that one of the many things the creator cannot do is to create a world where there is no suffering? I thought heaven was just such a world. Isn’t there a promise of a universe where, according to the author of the book of Revelation, ‘death will be no more; mourning and crying and pain will be no more’ (Revelation 21:4)?

I am tempted to also ask you about your one sentence dismissal of “Satan.” Are you one of those Christians who pick and choose what they are going to believe? Surely, Christians are required to believe in Satan; it is part of the package.
answer_text:
You have put your finger on what I think is the biggest problem with the traditional Christian view of God. For that view, God is necessary, so has no choice about what God does. Yet the creation of this universe is supposed to be free – God did not have to create this universe. God could have created another one, a better one, or no universe at all. This looks like a contradiction to me. Of course it all depends on what you think freedom is. Traditionalists think freedom means that nothing else compels you to do something. A great number of philosophers take this view. Then ‘God is free’ means that God does what God wants; nobody else compels God. But another view, the libertarian view, is that you are free only if you could really have done something else. If I do what is wrong, I usually could have done what is right. Or if I do what is right, I very easily could have failed to do it.

The libertarian view is the view I take. I do think the primal consciousness is free, and that means it could have acted in other ways in relation to the universe. To be precise, God is necessary in some ways – in existing and being good and wise, for example – and free in other ways – in choosing how to create and act in the universe.

If creativity is a great value, God will be creative. That will mean that God can do many new things. God will be able to generate beings who are free, who have many alternative choices in their lives. And God will be able to respond to their choices in new ways. Predestination – what God alone determines - will be true in some ways – humans will necessarily have brains and limited consciousness, for example. But not everything will be determined by God – humans have moral and intellectual choices of their own, which God will have to accept, and can then respond to.

The idea of God in the Bible, though it developed in many ways, looks like that. God is said to have talked with Abraham and Moses, and they sometimes changed God’s mind, and God praised or condemned people depending on what they did. So it seems odd that the traditional Christian view denied that God was free in the libertarian sense. Maybe it was because then you would face the problem of why God did not create a better world, when even we can think of one ( a world like heaven, for instance).

Yet God did create heaven and angels, after all. Perhaps God created many worlds, and this is one of the worse ones. And here is a thought. If it is good to create many sorts of value, there may be many worlds in which values and disvalues both exist. For instance, there may be great value in achieving good things by strenuous effort, or in overcoming obstacles and turning them into opportunities for good. In such worlds some disvalues would have to exist, but there would also be values that would not otherwise have existed. We can easily think of ordinary examples in our world: a nomadic desert life is hard and rigorous, but it offers rich and worth-while experiences that will never be felt by South Sea Islanders. Or again, many would choose a life of risk and adventure over a life of watching television.

I am not saying that this justifies the existence of terrible evils. But it does show that it may be better to face obstacles and overcome them than never to face hardships. I do not pretend to know all that is in God’s mind; but I think that many things are necessary for God and they may include the thought of many undesirable things. It may be necessary for God to create in order to realise the fulness of the divine nature as essentially relational.

Nevertheless, I would wish to avoid the thought that God chooses to create evil in order to realise some unique goods. I think that God does not choose evil; evil states necessarily arise from God, but not by God’s free choice. This universe is wholly intelligible, with integrated laws of nature ordering energies which are of cataclysmic destructive power as well as creative possibility. These polar forces are bound together and entangled, so that, for instance, the formation of volcanoes helps to produce the origin of life, and the collision of asteroids produces the formation of planets. The molecular changes which lead to more developed life-forms also produce viruses that maim and kill huge numbers of living things. Over millions of years conscious and intelligent life comes to exist, but only at the cost of much predation and death. All this necessarily arises from the primal consciousness, as the possibilities for creation and destruction which are entangled within it press into existence.

What God is free to do is to bring out of this tragic and beautiful world, filled with innumerable possibilities, many unique types of good, that otherwise could not have existed, culminating in a world of supreme and overwhelming goodness. In other words, God does not choose to create evil as a means to some greater good. God takes the evil which necessarily arises from the entangled possibilities in the divine nature, and seeks to bring unique sorts of good out of it. That complementary between necessity and free choice in God is essential if we are to hold that the universe is grounded in a God whose ultimate nature and purpose is loving.

We may think of God as necessarily creating a world which realises evil or destructive forces which are interlinked with many positive goods. Yet God is free to choose exactly which such world and which possible outcomes to bring into existence,  The story of the world will be one of how the disvalues are faced and overcome by the creative and co-operative efforts of many finite and the one divine consciousnesses.  In that way, we might say that  negative possibilities in God are negated or transformed by the actions of free created minds, in co-operation with God, bringing into being  communities of perfected love. If this is so, humans will be called to be co-workers with God in realizing, through struggle and endeavour, the goal of cosmic fulfilment.

We need to reject views of God which see God as freely deciding to create suffering when God need not have done so. Rather, in the primal consciousness many disvalues necessarily lie. Some of them become actual, not through desire, but by necessity, insofar as they are entangled as possibilities with certain sorts of value. The divine mind must then, insofar as it is free, seek to overcome them or turn them to good. Perhaps we may conjecture, as some scientists do, that our universe must have the law-like yet tragic nature that it does if it is to produce beings like the human species, with all its flaws and virtues.

You seem to suggest that you would feel sorry for a God who cannot help producing evil, and then has to fight against it. I understand that. But the Bible is full of stories of God fighting the great monster Leviathan, or Satan, both of whom God after all issued from God. And the story of Jesus’ crucifixion is a story of God suffering in order to bring about the good of overcoming evil and leading even imperfect and struggling beings to attain final beatitude in ‘heaven’, a much more perfect world. If God took part in this struggle, there would be sorrow, but there would also be joy, that even destruction and death could lead to unique forms of creative and reconciled life.

The idea that both God and intelligent creatures are necessary in some respects but free in others is a perfectly coherent idea. It helps to explain how imperfections can exist in a world created by God, and that some imperfections may even be necessary if creatures are to have the creative freedom to shape their own futures in partnership with God.

title: Question Six
choices: God constantly influences all situations but rarely determines outcomes; humans and nature retain genuine freedom.
God created the universe but does not intervene - deism is correct.
God directly controls all events, determining every outcome in history and nature.
Divine action is merely metaphorical language for natural processes.
God only acts through dramatic miracles that suspend natural law.
hint_wrong: The answer presents God as a constant influence on events without determining all outcomes - preserving both divine involvement and creaturely freedom.
explanation_right: God influences every situation as the wisest presence, but usually does not override human freedom or natural processes.
question_text:
– Divine Action

This is all very helpful. We have a primal consciousness that is necessary in some respects (wise, loving) and, in other respects, free and creative. In God’s Mind (is this too anthropomorphic to talk about God’s Mind – are we just turning God into a big person?), all possible worlds reside, some of which God could create and others (worlds where there is nothing but evil) which God could not create. In almost all universes, there are certain values and certain disvalues (presumably drawbacks) coexisting. God does choose to actualize particular universes (we know of at least two – heaven and earth) and what emerges will inevitably be a combination of good things and, in the production of those good things, necessary challenges. You stress it is not God choosing certain values that have the side effect of certain drawbacks, but that through the struggle of it all a universe emerges that necessarily lives with values and disvalues. This all makes sense.

Now once this universe is created, God does not simply sit back and allow the values and disvalues to coexist in this cosmic struggle. The Biblical witness has God deeply involved at every stage. God liberates the Jewish people from slavery in Egypt. God organizes history to both judge the people of God for their infidelity to the covenant and then, later, to liberate them from the captivity of the Babylonians. In the ministry of Jesus, we have healings from illness and demons. And in the Early Church, we have the Apostle Peter raise Tabitha from the dead. (Actus 9:36-43).

The God of the Bible controls history. We see Cyrus of the Persians being raised up by God to liberate the Jewish people. The God of the Bible controls the weather. We see a flood being sent to kill the people of the world because of their wickedness. And the God of the Bible blesses some people and curses others. We have that dramatic moment with the call of Abram in Genesis 12, where God promises to “bless those who bless you, and the one who curses you I will curse.” (Genesis 12:3). We have in the Bible a strong interventionist God.

Your account gives a very helpful explanation of why God allowed this sort of universe to emerge – necessarily, certain values were only possible in a universe like this. At the macro level, we have a helpful picture of why suffering and evil exist. But at the more micro level, we still have a major mystery. Why does this intervening God choose (because surely God is at this point exercising free will in your libertarian sense) to save some and not others? Why does one child with leukemia recover and the other one die? Why does John survive the car crash, but his brother, Joe, die in the car crash?

One route you could take is that God does not intervene. The Biblical images of a God of providences and miracles are not to be taken literally. Instead, these images are simply capturing the ways in which the values and disvalues are in a struggle within the creation. God does not really manipulate history, the weather, or curse and bless individuals. This, I suppose, does have the advantage of clarity and simplicity. But of course, one loses so much. God seems to be a cosmic voyeur, and this is not how the Church thinks of God.

So, the question now is this: do you believe in a God who is an active agent in creation? And if so, how does God choose when and where to intervene?
answer_text:
You are right to point out that we should not think of God as a big person. If I speak of God’s mind, this may sound like a human mind – it is conscious and it acts. But its awareness is non-sensory and embraces all that exists or could exist, and it brings into being and sustains the whole universe. This is a form of knowledge and action that we cannot even imagine.

Many believers in God have thought this means that everything is God’s action. Yet they also often believe that humans are free even to rebel against God. This is very odd, unless you think that God can create beings whose acts are not wholly determined by God, who can to some extent determine their own futures. God will set the limits of human action, so that in many situations there will be a number of possible paths into the future, but God will not determine which path will be taken.

Individual humans will not make choices entirely on their own. They are members of social groups, and they will be influenced by the choices and values of others. Some individuals will be more creative, adventurous, or wiser than others, while some will be more likely to follow what others do. God, who has a purpose in creation, will be by far the wisest and most creative influence in any situation, and will naturally have a preferred path or paths into the future. So God will be a major influence in every situation, but one that may be ignored or even misinterpreted.

Further, God’s influence may be greater in some situations than in others, and there is always a possibility that there are some situations where God does determine what happens, though this cannot happen too often  if human freedom is to be protected. At such points, the world ‘miracle’ may be appropriate – an extraordinary event of special significance forwarding God’s overall purposes,  in which a sense of the presence of God becomes clear.

Many religions record miracles, usually associated with holy persons who have a strong sense of relationship to God. Just as some people are better musicians or athletes than others, so some people will have a greater insight into the divine will than others, and will be more open to God’s influence. It is not that God just decides to break a law of nature (that is David Hume’s strange definition of a miracle) to help somebody God likes. It is rather that the extremely complex set of human choices, which is often filled with controversy and competition,  unusually converges on a focal point in history where the influence of God is able to be expressed with greater clarity.

The Bible records many such instances, and Jesus’ healings and especially his resurrection are extraordinary events that reveal God’s special action. If the resurrection is the appearing in our spacetime of one who has passed into a higher plane of being, it breaks no law of nature, yet is an unprecedented event determined by God in a historical context which has made possible  this revelation of God’s final purpose for humanity.

Far from being a passive spectator of human affairs, God is a constant influence on all affairs. From this point of view, there are three main factors at work in every event. There are the mathematically elegant laws off nature, which ensure that events are not simply arbitrary and accidental. There is an element of creative indeterminism, which allows for alternative paths into the future, and prevents events from being completely predetermined. And there is the attractive influence of the goals, present in the divine mind, of increasing consciousness and directed action that ensure there is a general purposiveness in the cosmic process. These factors are forms of divine action,  and when intelligent life  evolves, the divine influence takes two more particular forms. In finite conscious  beings, there is to various degrees a sense of vocation or of moral obligation (knowledge of a preferred possibility or apprehension of the future), and there is a sense of intellectual or moral empowerment to  act in purposeful ways.

Humans do not always consciously experience such things, and even if they do, they do not have to accept their influence. Some humans are more aware of them, and are often able to respond positively. Also,  some historical situations are such that divine influence becomes stronger and clearer. Due to the large number and variety of human decisions, and the historical contexts in which they occur, many of them are not in accord with God’s preferred possibility (God’s will), and what actually happens is usually impossible to predict. In a Biblical perspective, there are prophets who discern the way that God acts to promote (bless) good and to frustrate (curse) evil. Jesus in particular is seen by Christians as one with clear knowledge of God’s will, and as filled with God’s power to fulfil it. That, however, for them, is a virtually unique case, and much of human history is mainly the result of many complex natural causes and human decisions. In our world, God’s promoting and frustrating of natural processes and human acts is difficult to discern, but Christian faith is that it is a vital factor in individual and social history, that it is disclosed in a special way in some ‘revelatory’ events, and that it is destined to lead, perhaps beyond this world, to the fulfilment of finite lives in the conscious knowledge and love of God.

title: Question seven
choices: Death is final; talk of afterlife is wishful thinking unsupported by evidence.
Mind and brain are not identical - consciousness can exist beyond physical death in a spiritual realm.
Physical resurrection of the same body is essential to Christian hope.
We are reincarnated into new physical bodies repeatedly.
Only the soul matters; the body is a prison to escape permanently.
hint_wrong: The answer argues that materialism (mind = brain) is philosophical, not scientific - consciousness may well survive bodily death.
explanation_right: The claim that death ends consciousness is a philosophical position, not a scientific finding - idealism suggests mind can exist beyond the body.
question_text:
– Life after death

This is all very compelling. So, God does act but does so in ways that honors God’s creation. When we talk of events in time, you talk about three main ways and then two ways in which God works with humans. The three main ways are the laws of nature (God’s carefully regulated world in which we live), creative indeterminism (God allows us – and presumably God also - to have real choices about which future trajectory will unfold), and then the divine goals (so God is constantly trying and, presumably, will ultimately ensure that a particular set of goals will be realized, even with the various turns and twists on the journey). Then humans are being shaped by the divine life in two important ways: the first is in respect to our sense of vocation and calling; and the second is the way God gives us the intellectual and moral capacity to take a particular course of action that moves us ever closer to one of those divine goals.

Our theodicy, then, does recognize that this is a particular universe (one of numerous possible universes that God could have created), which has certain values and, inevitability, some challenges. One value is that God still has space to act, but God does so within a framework. You recognize the regulated natural laws that ensure life is not arbitrary or haphazard; and God is constantly acting in cooperation with or sometimes against uncooperative humanity; and God is constantly calling us to cooperate with certain divine goals, realize our vocation to do good, and be granted the capacity to succeed. The gift of this this account is that you recognize the reality of evil and suffering, you explain how it is one of the inevitable challenges of a certain universe which has certain values, and you have a picture of human agency and divine agency that in a very real sense is an invitation for humanity to do what we can to alleviate suffering in this world by doing less evil ourselves and by helping others who are suffering.

I am a little surprised that your account did not mention the life to come. I think I tend to the view that if there is no afterlife and that this life is it, then it would be hard for God to have created this world. The sheer quantity of suffering in this universe is massive. We need to have a bigger canvas on which God is working. This is part of the Christian claim. You mentioned in passing the resurrection of Jesus as an illustration of a human passing to a higher plane of being and that then this higher plane of existence is occasionally visible to the disciples. This does mean that you have an account of the life to come – the higher plane.

Perhaps we could just pause here for a moment. The life to come is viewed by our skeptical friend as an attractive idea (after all, many of us would like to believe that death is not the end) but in the end implausible. Science shows us that once the brain dies, the mind dies with it. And anyway, if I die in a cancer-ridden body at the ripe old age of 95, then I am not sure I just want to be resurrected with my decrepit body. Then there is the problem of what exactly I am imagining. Is heaven a disembodied timeless reality? And will I find aliens and animals there? And what do you do with hell? Finally, is the afterlife part of your theodicy as well?
answer_text:
It is just not true that science shows that when the brain dies the mind dies with it. That is materialism, the philosophical belief that mind and brain are inseparable, or, in its extreme form, that they are the same thing. That is not a scientific belief, but a philosophical one, and most philosophers throughout history have denied it. Anyone who believes in God, or in a primal consciousness which is the source of the whole physical cosmos, is committed to saying that mind is prior to matter and can exist without it. For non-materialist philosophers, conscious experience, feeling, and purposive intention, are different in kind from any material object, and could exist without any material objects, as they do in God.

Of course, as a matter of fact, human consciousness is embodied in a physical body and brain, and destroying the brain will cut off all connections of the brain with consciousness. What that means is that consciousness can no longer be expressed in the physical world. It does not entail that minds will no longer exist in any form. Since the natural sciences deal only with the physical world, they can, as sciences, have no opinion on whether there is a non-embodied mind (God) or on whether human minds continue to exist after brain-death or not.

Most religions affirm that minds (traditionally called ‘souls’) do continue to exist after bodily death, and only lack of imagination will deny that possibility. Christianity, with its belief in the resurrection of Jesus, certainly affirms life after death. But there may seem a complication, for is this not the resurrection of the body? And is that not scientifically impossible? Physical bodies do not, having disintegrated, come back to life!

There has been a lot of misunderstanding about this, even though the Christian view is fairly clearly stated in a New Testament letter, 1 Corinthians, chapter 15. The letter was written by Paul, who claimed to have seen the resurrected Jesus, though what he saw was not a physical body, but ‘a light from heaven’ (Acts, 9, 3). What Paul wrote was that ‘the body that is sown is perishable, it is raised imperishable’. He elaborates by saying that the body that dies is a sense-orientated natural body (soma psychikon) while the resurrected body is a spiritual body (soma pneumatikon).  The translations of the Greek are hard to interpret, but what is clear is that they are different sorts of body. What lives after physical death is not a disembodied soul. It is embodied; that is, it exists in a shared environment that enables persons to receive information, to act in that environment, and to communicate with others.  In other words, human beings, and perhaps other finite beings also, continue as individual persons who exist in a community of persons, and who change and develop as they interact. But their bodies are imperishable, so they are certainly not part of this physical cosmos, which is essentially subject to decay and death (the inescapable laws of entropy).

After physical death, then, according to this Christian view, human minds are re-embodied in a different realm of being. The resurrection of the body is not the resuscitation of some physical body. It is the transfer of a consciousness into a different form of body in a different world.  What it will be like there we cannot know, for when Jesus appeared in our cosmos he took the form of the physical body he used to have, but had no longer.

Each person lives in that new world, and it is there that they receive the consequences for good or ill that flow from their previous life in the physical world. There have been many different views of what this will be like, even among Christians. i think the basic axiom of Christian faith is that God desires the well-being of every creature. but we know that humans are free to love and care for others or to hate and harm them. We know that many cause horrific suffering and destruction, and perhaps that all fail to do the good that they should have done.

Given these facts, it follows that, if one goal of creation is the existence of a loving community of persons with each other and with God, many people will need help to become able truly and unreservedly to love others, and to eliminate the elements of self-regard that prevent them doing so. This suggests the existence of multiple worlds, through which souls will pass before they attain the state of supreme love which is their final goal.  That is, there will be many heavens of increasing goodness, not just one perfect heaven.

There are millions of people who have suffered in this world, either through the acts of others or from natural disasters. In an afterlife, they will be able to realize the possibilities that were denied them in this life. There will also be those who have fallen prey to hatred and greed, and who have caused great harm to others. For them, there would be many ‘hells’, where souls will suffer the self-inflicted torments of living in worlds where hatred and greed are experienced by them in their full destructive power. Yet divine love could never be purely destructive.  Therefore such torment would always be for the sake of reforming evil inclinations, would never be endless  and would always offer the eventual possibility of repentance and forgiveness.

If God is love, an endless hell cannot exist. In every hell, there will be the possibility of turning towards heaven, though the reality of human freedom means that, terrible though it may seem, not all may choose heaven and the presence of God. In that case, I believe that hell, in all its forms, will eventually cease to exist. The goal of the cosmos will be achieved, and all will be well.

I admit that this is speculative, though it seems to follow from any assumption that the primal consciousness, insofar as it is free, is also wise and good. It gives finite existence meaning, value, and purpose. and it enables one to see that earthly life is a journey through conflict and hardship to lasting union and joy. This, to me, is the basic Christian faith, even though, in its details, it is not agreed by all Christians. The Biblical record, while it contains many different views of afterlife (the idea of bodily resurrection is a fairly late development in the Old Testament), contains many passages which support a view very like this one. For the mercy and compassion of God, shown in Jesus, is stronger than the purely destructive condemnation that is the just response to evil.

title: Question Eight
choices: Church hierarchy is essential and its authority should not be questioned.
The Church is divinely protected from error; its failures are exaggerated by enemies.
Churches, like all human institutions, are corruptible - but the goal of loving community remains valid despite failures.
Church corruption proves Christianity is false and should be abandoned.
Only invisible, non-institutional Christianity is authentic.
hint_wrong: The answer acknowledges church failures as real while maintaining that the goal of loving community remains valid.
explanation_right: Human institutions inevitably fall short, but this doesn't invalidate the divine purpose they imperfectly serve.
question_text:
– Why does the Church behave in oppressive ways?

Although speculative, there is a beautiful plausibility to your account. Materialism is implausible. A primal consciousness creates and wants a ‘loving community of persons’ (I will come back to that in a moment). Based on the resurrection of Jesus, the Christian claim is that consciousness inhabits a different body on a different plane. Ultimately, God’s hope for a hell free cosmos will be realized, but for a season many of us might need to work on our lives so that we are fully focused on God and each other.

Now, I have already paused on that phrase you used, when you wrote that the primal consciousness wants “the existence of a loving community of persons with each other and with God.” And I think this is where we need to go next.

For many of our skeptical friends, Church is a big reason for skepticism about religion. It is an institution with a very mixed record. Granted there are the saints – St. Francis of Assisi, Mother Teresa of Calcutta, and Martin Luther King Jr., but these seem like isolated models of goodness in an institution that at times can be so ugly.

It is strange how an institution that is called to witness to the themes of love and justice often ends up being unloving and unjust. From women to LGBT plus persons, the church has been intolerant and sometimes cruel. From Emperor Constantine onwards, the church has been an ally of power and often focused on its own financial self-interest. To the outsider, the secular Enlightenment taught the world about equality, democracy, toleration, and freedom. The Church tended to be opposed to these changes.

Perhaps this is all too simplistic. But this basic picture for our skeptical friends is assumed, namely, the Church is reluctant to change and afraid to affirm basic rights for minorities. And the Church’s role in the slave trade, empire, and colonialization is not good. When we do get it right, we tend to turn up late in the game. We are rarely at the vanguard of justice issues and only play ‘catch up’ when the secular justice organizations have largely won.

The question then is this: If there is a primal consciousness that wants this loving community of persons, then why is the Church so tardy and, often, resistant to justice orientated trends and movements?
answer_text:
I think your question comes down to this: if God wants a loving community of persons, why do humans do their best to frustrate what God wants? And if the Churches are divinely inspired, how can they also all too often frustrate what God wants?

I need to expand the idea of what God wants, and to do so by reference to the life of Jesus, who is after all believed by Christians to be the human image of God. Jesus and his disciples were meant to be just the sort of loving community God desires. According to the New Testament record, while Jesus succeeded in fulfilling his part in this purpose, the disciples failed miserably. They quarreled over who was the greatest, Peter lied about being a disciple, and they constantly misunderstood what Jesus was teaching. Jesus was betrayed by one disciple and deserted by the others. The earliest churches split into competing sects, and they have remained in that state ever since.

There are Christians who think this was all just what God wanted, or even what God planned and made happen. But it seems more likely to me that it was not at all what God wanted. As John’s Gospel puts it,  ‘He came to what was his own, and his own people  did not receive him’ (John 1, 11). They were free to reject him. God wanted them to be free, even if it meant rejecting the messenger of God.

This shows an important factor in the nature of love and of personhood. There are many sorts of love, and one of them is care for the well-being of others, care that is not just admiration of their power or beauty or wisdom, but that helps them in distress, supports them when they fail, and seeks to heal them when they suffer. Love of the just, wise, and beautiful is the appropriate love for primal mind, the archetype and source of all. It requires accurate perception of what justice and beauty is, and a self-transcending regard for what is truly worth-while. It requires purity of vision, and a moral commitment to actions which seek to realise these ideals in the physical world.

Thus it can be said that, when rightly seen, this love entails the more practical love of those in need, who for whatever reason lack the wisdom or power that should be possible for them. It is true that such practical love does exist, and is of great value, in those to whom  the love of something so seemingly abstract as Beauty seems more fantastic or imaginary than real. In that sense, moral commitment does not depend on belief in, much less love for, God. Yet if love for God Is genuine, it provides a basis in the very nature of things (not just a personal preference) for altruism and compassion.

The sting is in that phrase ‘if the love for God is genuine’.  If love requires accurate perception and self-transcending regard, it is not just a sudden infatuation. It requires effort, persistence, and practical commitment to cultivating honesty, creativity, and compassion. Honesty is the virtue that prompts the search for knowledge,  discovery and co-operation in finding truth. Creativity leads to bringing form and harmony out of chaos, and being committed to appreciation of many forms of beauty.  Compassion requires understanding of and care for others. These virtues are entailed by genuine love for God. They are difficult to practice and sustain, and easy to compromise or ignore. Because they require such effort, their very existence implies the possibility of not making the effort, of being less than truthful, creative, and sympathetic.

Thus belief in God can evoke an authoritarian suppression of uncomfortable truths, an insistence on traditional rules that deplore new creative insights, and a fear and dislike of those who differ from oneself. Religious institutions, which should inspire a continuing search for greater understanding, for awe and delight in the natural world, and insistence on kindness so far as is possible to all, may become opposed to new knowledge, haters of the pleasures of the natural world, and even violent enemies of those who do not accept their views.

Most religious institutions, like most human institutions, including Christian churches, will both preach the virtues of love, and ignore them in practice. They will, perhaps like many individuals, be mixtures of moral demand and heroism, and of notable moral failure and cowardice. Virtue is extremely difficult, and since churches stress the need for penitence a great deal, they must also be full of moral failures (those who ‘miss the mark’, as the  Greek of the New Testament puts it). The problem is they often forget this and think they have already attained what they hope for, and are somehow better than other people.

Why should humans be free to reject God’s will? It is often said, because free creativity is a great good. That is true, but there is more to it than this. Chaos and destruction lie as possibilities in the mind of God. They are not chosen by God; but they are necessarily part of the foundation of being. God has a history, and that is the exposure of the destructive possibilities of being, and their defeat by the power of love. For Christians, the mystery of the world is  that even what is most alienated from God can be eliminated in its negativity and reconciled to God. Finite souls are born into a world of conflict and oppression (as Jesus was), so that by the practice of virtue they can overcome such evils. They are born to be reconcilers of an alienated world to God.

In this they largely fail, as the temptations of individual power, wealth, and pleasure, in the world and in the churches, undermine the ideals of self-transcending love that define the final purpose of cosmic history. The good news Jesus brought is that failure can be forgiven, and penitent but imperfect souls can be empowered by God to form, in higher worlds than this, a communion of creative and compassionate souls that have encountered, endured, and conquered the forces of decay and death, and become fellow-workers with God and sharers in the divine love. The Christian churches (I use the plural advisedly) exist to relay this good news, but they should not be confused with the perfected communion which God wills for the whole world. To put it in Christian language, the Kingdom of God has come near in Jesus the Christ, so that in his name humans can find forgiveness, the help of the indwelling divine Spirit, and the promise of final fulfilment, but the full realisation of the Kingdom lies in a new creation.

title: Question Nine
choices: Ethics requires divine command; without God, everything is permitted.
Only consequences matter; there are no intrinsic moral values.
Moral truths are absolute and knowable with certainty through Scripture alone.
Moral knowledge is real but gradual and fallible - we learn through dialogue across perspectives.
Morality is entirely relative; there are no objective ethical truths.
hint_wrong: The answer holds that moral truth exists but our knowledge of it develops gradually and benefits from multiple perspectives.
explanation_right: Objective moral truth exists, but humans access it gradually, fallibly, and through learning from diverse viewpoints.
question_text:
– Knowledge of moral truth

I suppose we all live in a place where self-deception distorts our understanding of ourselves, our understanding of the moral sphere, and our relationships with God and each other.
