A key word is “sin”, which I note you did not use. This is wise. Such traditional language can be difficult for our secular friend. The narrative instead is that God has placed a high value on freedom – it is as you say the vehicle to chaos, which then creates the necessity of reconciliation in an alienated world. This freedom means that we can be self-deceived about justice and love. The result is churches that “preach the virtues of love, and ignore them in practice.”

The key themes are God’s freedom, the quest for self-transcendental love, the inevitable self-deception, and the resulting moral blindness and resistance. This all makes sense. However, let us dig a little more here.

Let us try a little exercise. Augustine of Hippo from the fifth century and Thomas Aquinas from the thirteenth century – two giants of the Church – thought that both democracy and homosexuality were incompatible with the teachings of the Church. Democracy is problematic because it is potentially mob rule and God alone has determined the appropriate ruler, while homosexuality is a sin against nature. Both were sincere. Both were deeply morally serious. Both had Biblical texts that they could invoke for their position. There are no texts in the Bible explicitly endorsing either democracy or homosexuality. So, where exactly is the moral blindness here?

There are two questions here. The first is how exactly do we determine what God wants in society? What is our methodology whereby we discover moral truth? Is it intuition, the Bible, deductions from the God-intended order for society (my definition of natural law) or the Christian tradition? The second is that we are both committed to LGBT plus inclusion and to democracy. But how do we know that we are both right? Could we be self-deceived?
answer_text:
I have accepted throughout this conversation that there are many different human views about the nature of reality and of value. It is not true that one of them is clearly superior to the others, and is accepted by all rational people. Intelligent and informed people hold different views on these matters. Some hold that there is no God and no objective value or purpose, while others disagree. Yet this does not mean that they are all equally true. Since they often contradict each other, that cannot be the case. We all hold views for which there is no conclusive evidence, and it is surprising, and irrational, that so many people, both religious and non-religious, hold that theirs is the only correct view, and even persecute those who disagree with them. Therefore no one can be certain, in the strict sense that no rational person could disagree,  about what God wants, or even of whether there is a God. This ought to establish the principle of freedom of conscience, that people will not be persecuted simply for disagreement, and it should end such persecution by believers and unbelievers alike.

However, though we cannot be logically certain of any such views, we can, and often must be, wholly committed to some of them. For example, when considering the permissibility of abortion, we know that equally intelligent and informed people take different views, so no view is indisputably correct. Yet we must wholly commit ourselves to one view in practice. Similarly, with belief in God, we must either totally trust in God or not, and that is a life-changing yet not demonstrable decision.

It is important, however, that such decisions should be rational. Belief in the priority of mind, for instance, should be consistent with other well-established facts, especially of the sort found in the natural sciences. Such knowledge can change rapidly, and may often be controversial. So this principle leaves open the possibility of a plurality of interpretations. There is not just one rational view, but at least efforts should be made to achieve a consistent, coherent, comprehensive, and informed knowledge of relevant facts – for instance, of the age and size and development of the cosmos, or of human genetics.  By this criterion, medical studies of human gender and sexuality are important in making moral judgments about homosexuality. Some moral judgments have been based on inaccurate information, especially in the area of sexuality, and they may need changing.

Augustine could have known little of these things, and probably associated homosexuality with depravity, so his views would certainly need revising. As for Aquinas and democracy, the social conditions for democracy simply did not then exist, but the ‘kingdom’ of which Jesus spoke was a community of free brothers and sisters, all of whom had equal dignity and respect under God. This is the ‘liberty, equality, and fraternity’ so often attributed to the anticlerical French revolution, but in fact is an essential part of the Christian ideal. If social conditions changed – and they did – it may turn out that some form of democracy (not yet achieved) is a worthy political aim.

For theists the idea of revelation is also important. If there is a supreme conscious agent, God, with a purpose in generating the physical universe, we would expect some form of revelation of that purpose. If God is a loving creator, as in Christianity, God would be concerned with all creatures, not with one small social group of humans. There are claims  to revelation in most cultures. They differ markedly in what they say. Yet it is possible to discern a common core in many of them. That is an idea of a goal for human lives which involves delivery from greed, hatred, and harm, and entrance into a state of knowledge, bliss, and freedom from suffering – and also, perhaps, includes some form of punishment for wrong-doing. That is what we find in many religions of the world, even though the details vary considerably.

Of course they cannot all be correct, and so we must say that  most revelations contain some errors of various sorts (we all say that about revelations that contradict our own),  as well as the hope for liberation from evil by relation to a higher spiritual reality. The Abrahamic tradition (Judaism, Christianity, and Islam, among others) focusses on the hope of forgiveness of wrong-doing and a fulfilling personal life in relation to God. In the case of Judaism, the prophets (according to Christians) were often wrong in predicting that Israel would become the leading world state, or that the Messiah would be a political leader. Views of God developed in the Old Testament from an early polytheism and from a God who commended genocide (Deuteronomy 20, 16) to a rigorous monotheism and a God of mercy and compassion. Even though important truths about God’s nature and purpose are revealed, these are mixed with many human speculations and limitations of outlook. There is change and development within this tradition, not one unchanging set of truths which are unaffected by human thought and interpretation. At least that is what many  Jews might say. And since inspection of other traditions leads to similar conclusions, we might reasonably expect  such change and development to be to exist in most religious traditions.

Christianity arguably erred in thinking that Jesus would return within a generation, or that Hell was  everlasting.  Jesus did not return within a generation in glory,  and many Christians have come to agree that a God who is loving would not torture people for ever without hope of reprieve.

The fact that many Christian churches  disagree about fairly important matters shows that there is not just one version  of exactly what is revealed in Christian faith.  Some Christians think that since we should love our enemies, we should be pacifists (Quakers). Some think that since Jesus criticized divorce, divorce should not be allowed (Roman Catholics).  Some think that since Jesus apparently said that he was the only way to the Father, non-Christians cannot be saved (Protestant fundamentalists). Some think that since the New Testament says, ‘I do not permit a woman …to have authority over a man’ (1 Timothy 2, 12), all women should obey men. Yet all these views are denied by many churches.

They are denied because moral views change even within the Bible, and they change partly because of reflection on what a God of forgiveness and universal love would do. God does not change; it is human ideas of God that change. In the history of Christian thought, slavery and the inferiority of women, capital punishment and the killing of unbelievers, all once thought to be justified in the Bible by a careful selection of texts, have, after many arguments, come to be seen as inconsistent with belief in a God of self-giving love.

Once the Torah, the Jewish Law, had been rejected, as it was by Christians, the Bible gives very few specific moral rules. With regard to politics, the advice it does give is very misleading – it recommends obeying rulers however evil they are! (Romans 13). A way was soon found, probably after rulers  started killing Christians, to reverse this advice, and there have been many Christian revolutionary (as well as many Christian fascist) movements. Democracy, never commended Biblically, just seems to  many to be the least bad way of obtaining a society of loving and responsible people. And that seems to be what a loving God would desire. Christian moral rules are not given as precise and unchangeable orders which are clear to any rational person. They have to be painfully worked out as ways, often in new circumstances, to realise the central moral principles of justice, concern for the disadvantaged, and compassion, which were manifested in the life of Jesus.

This means that there is not just one ‘secular morality’ that is opposed to  one ‘Christian morality’. There has been a deepening focus on what is  probably the central belief of Christian faith, that the primal consciousness, God, shares in the human condition of suffering and alienation in order that humans –  all humans – could share in the self-giving, forgiving, joyful, and enriching, kindness and compassion of God.

This central belief, even within the Bible, co-exists with some more negative beliefs that stress God’s vengeance on those who reject God, or with local cultural attitudes to women and slaves  and dissenters – attitudes that are undermined by other texts in the New Testament which point to God’s desire eventually to include all things in Christ (Ephesians 1, 9), as well as by the central belief in God’s universal love.

We are all disabled by self-regard and  self-deception. Revelation does not eliminate that fact. We may believe that some experienced facts (revelations) communicate the meaning and purpose of our lives. But the history of so many differing alleged revelations teaches that our interpretation is that of very imperfect minds, and needs to be tested by careful thought and wide experience. There is no guarantee that we are not mistaken.

Nevertheless theists must seek to  determine what God wants. We can do so  in two main ways. First, by asking what states make for human flourishing and well-being. Religion is not needed here, though it is not irrelevant. This is one sort of Natural (moral) Law approach. Second, for Christians, by seeing in the life of Jesus the sort of God there is – a God who shares in human suffering, who has special concern for the poor and outcast, who demands justice, humility, and compassion, but who forgives without limit, and desires all people to share in the happiness, love, and wisdom of life in union with primal mind. This makes  morality objectively demanding, yet also offers the hope that moral failure can be forgiven and true fulfilment achieved, if only by divine help. That combination of reserve and commitment gives to the moral life a unique and distinctive character which is concerned with ultimate human well-being as seen in the revelation of God’s purpose in the life of Jesus Christ.

title: Question Ten
choices: Holiness comes instantly through a single conversion experience.
Holiness is achieved through rigorous ascetic practices and self-denial.
Holiness is an outdated concept irrelevant to modern spirituality.
Holiness means strict separation from the sinful world and its pleasures.
Holiness is growing toward wholeness - becoming a loving, serving person empowered by divine presence.
hint_wrong: The answer presents holiness as growth toward wholeness and love, empowered by God, rather than separation or instant achievement.
explanation_right: Holiness means reaching one's proper goal - becoming a loving person who serves others, aided by divine power.
question_text:
Holiness

This is all very compelling. Given, rationally, we are not granted certainty in ethics, we should be assuming that we need to live in a society where people should be free to articulate their understanding of the ethical so we can all learn from such perspectives. From this premise, the discovery of ethical truth is a gradual process that needs to accommodate insights from other disciplines (for example, science). In addition, one should not be surprised that some of the great theologians of the past did not have the conceptual framework to imagine a democracy. And even now we have a diversity of perspectives in the church – on abortion, divorce, and salvation of the non-Christian – that is indicative of the challenge of working out ethical truth. Now you still want to stress ‘revelation’, but you also want to stress that it is difficult to know precisely what is being revealed. Nevertheless, there is a truth to be discovered and perhaps with an appropriate focus on “human flourishing” we can slowly move towards that truth. This, coupled with what we learn of God in Christ Jesus, is a framework that can create parameters around ethical truth. This is all really good.

However, a key theme of the Christian tradition is that God gives us the resources to be good. Our propensities to sin and selfishness can be overcome in some sense by Christ on the cross. For our Evangelical friends, we are all living with the consequences of the Fall. In Adam we have all sinned (Romans 5:12) but in Christ we can all be made alive (or righteous, as St. Paul would put it). On this account, the Fall has distorted our understanding of the ethical. We are mired in sin and in an inability to see what makes for “human flourishing” because of our inherited sin from Adam – the original sin. What we need is for God to take the initiative. We can only escape the impact of sin by acknowledging the centrality of the cross – the saving work of God in Christ.

Now I suspect you would say that the evangelical framing of the tradition is an over-simplification. However, let us work through the following questions. First, to what extent has the Fall (perhaps disentangled from an historical event and focused on the idea that the Fall describes all the human propensities to selfishness and egoism) distorted our capacity to know moral truth and live a moral life? What is your understanding of original sin? Second, what do you make of the claim that somehow in the death of Jesus we can be saved from our sins? What is your atonement theory?
answer_text:
I have suggested that the moral life begins with intuitions about what makes for human well-being. The revelation of God in the person of Jesus, for Christians, fills out those intuitions with the ideal of a loving, serving, reconciling community of morally free persons, empowered by the divine help of the living Christ. But there is no precise and changeless set of rules (‘the letter kills, but the Spirit gives life’ wrote St. Paul, in 2 Corinthians, 3, 6) which must be obeyed to the letter, and no sudden transformation of ambiguous and self-centred lives into totally wise and loving saints (‘the good that I would I do not, but the evil that I would not, that I do’, Paul wrote in Romans, 7, 19).  The Christian moral life is one of continual reflection and change, as deeper insights into what love requires hopefully arise. And even the most pious life is never free from usually unperceived elements of self love and restricted vision.

It is true that the command to love is absolute. But what love requires is hard to discern, and if the ‘sermon on the mount’ (Matthew 5 – 7) is to be taken seriously, it is even harder to put into practice. Some Christians speak of ‘original sin’, but I find this both morally dubious and based on a misinterpretation of the story of Adam and Eve in the creation myths of the book of Genesis. It is morally dubious if it implies (as Augustine did) that children, even before they have done anything, are guilty or at least morally imperfect and opposed to God. The misinterpretation is largely due to not realising  that Genesis is a mythical story of human origins, one that is not historically true (God never walked in a garden, trying to find Adam) but is meant to convey spiritual truths in poetic and symbolic form. Even then, the idea that sinfulness is somehow inherited from one’s ancestors confuses genetic and moral issues, and is foreign to Jewish readings of the text.

What the idea of original sin (a basically Latin idea) seeks to capture is a sense of estrangement from God and an inability to know or do what is right. Paul puts this well when he writes, ‘As in Adam all die, so in Christ shall all be made alive’ (1 Corinthians 15, 22).

Scientific research in the last two hundred years provides a new, if incomplete, historical account of human origins. As complex life forms evolved, animals needed to reproduce and survive. It was natural to develop aggressive and sexually active forms of behaviour which could advance these aims. But close emotional ties and co-operative activity were equally necessary. Thus humans from the first needed to balance the two forces of aggressive dominance and co-operative affection. The Genesis story of ‘ Eating fruit from the tree of knowledge’ can effectively be seen as a symbol of a long process in early human history, one of gradually learning how to let co-operation outweigh aggression. This was the beginning of the moral struggle which has ever since marked human history.

In that struggle, early humanity failed. Co-operation and affection became more difficult to achieve, and the sense of a guiding spiritual force grew dimmer. Now, many generations later, humans  are born into a society where goodness seems  rare and onerous, and God seems powerless to act. We, ‘beings in Adam’ – that is, in our inherited animal nature – inevitably fail to achieve our moral destiny. What we ought, we cannot do. What we should love, we cannot see. And so we die, day by day, estranged from God, the source and goal of abundant life. That could be called ‘original sin’ – though a better term would be ‘estrangement from God’, from the goodness we are called to pursue.

Many religions are concerned with this problem, and it often leads to fear of the gods or spirits, and to sometimes bloody sacrificial rituals to appease them. Christian faith affirms one creator God who desires the ultimate well-being of all people, and does not require the sacrifice of animals to appease God’s wrath. Sacrifice was an important part of ancient Jewish tradition, but there was also a recognition that God desired not animal sacrifice, but moral reform and purity of heart (‘I desire mercy and not sacrifice’: Hosea 6, 6).  When early Christians abandoned Torah, the Jewish law, they also abandoned animal sacrifice as a symbol of a life offered to God. Jesus was seen as the perfect sacrifice of a life wholly given to God, and that sacrifice could never be repeated.

The life of Jesus as a whole, with its readiness to face death in the face of evil, and its visible transfiguration after physical death, is a human image of a God who shares in the pains of the world, and desires the fulfilment of all humanity in the world to come. Pictures of Jesus on the cross are frequent throughout the Christian world, and are expressions of the pain Jesus endured in his resistance to evil. They  also show the pain God endures when creation is destroyed by human greed and hatred. But Jesus was not destroyed by pain and death; he lives in a transfigured form in the spiritual world (‘heaven’). Similarly, God is not destroyed by the evils of the world, but seeks to reconcile all things to the divine life.

It seems clear that humans cannot achieve perfection by sheer effort. But it is possible that they might turn to God and ask for divine help to make them more genuinely loving. Only God can perfect humanity. Humans are not only ‘in Adam’ – part of failed humanity. They are also ‘in Christ’ – part of humanity which the eternal Christ raises to life with God. Christ has to descend to the lowest depths of estrangement from and even antagonism to God and goodness to begin to draw people to true repentance. Christ’s purpose is not to die; God does not desire or require a death in order to forgive sin. Jesus’ death was caused by the  rejection of Christ’s purpose by a world estranged from God. Christ’s purpose is to call even the worst of sinners to repentance, to redeem the whole universe. For Christ is the one in whom the whole universe will be united (Ephesians 1). That redemption is costly, for it experiences and feels what has been defaced and destroyed in creation, and so is sorrowful and  compassionate. Then it works to reconcile all things to the divine life, which is difficult and often of little effect. What sort of God would choose sorrow and disappointment over unchanging beatitude? Not the God of Aristotle, free from the costs of a truly free creation. But a God revealed in the life of a man who lived among the poor and outcastes and died at the hands of those he tried to heal and reform.

Because Jesus is the Christ, we can say that he is the one who dies for us, that we might live. But we must be careful to say that it is God who saves in and through Jesus. It is not just a human death which saves, but the suffering of God as it experiences the horror of an estranged world, and unites with a human life which suffers death.

And it is not, properly speaking, the death which saves. It is the Christ life which cannot die, which carries that human life beyond physical death, and which tirelessly works to reclaim human lives for itself. That is the atonement, the making-one of humanity with God.

There is no sacrifice that humans can bring to God. The only true sacrifice is God’s own renunciation of changeless bliss, and it is the self-offering of the man God has united to the divine. It is the entrance of the deathless into the world of death, in order that the dying may receive life. The cross is the cost of that gift, and all that humans can offer is lives offered to the crucified God. Repentance, trust, and obedience is the only appropriate human response to the transforming power of the eternal Christ, which was manifest and mediated on earth in Jesus. Thus atonement is the free gift of divine life, not some sort of tricky deal with devil or the imposition of an enormous penalty on an innocent man. The life, death, and resurrection of Jesus manifests in history the suffering, forgiving, transforming, and victorious actions of a God who wills the fulfilment and well-being of all humanity.

title: Question Eleven
choices: Original sin is better understood as universal estrangement from God - a condition we all share, not inherited guilt.
Sin is an outdated concept; humans are naturally good.
Original sin is inherited guilt transmitted biologically from Adam.
Sin only applies to deliberate individual moral failures.
Humans are totally depraved and incapable of any good without grace.
hint_wrong: The answer reframes original sin as estrangement rather than inherited guilt - a universal human condition needing healing.
explanation_right: Original sin captures the truth of universal human estrangement from God without the problematic notion of inherited guilt.
question_text:
– Holiness part two

I do appreciate the way you reframe a doctrine. So ‘original sin’ and ‘atonement’ are both reframed in such a way that you affirm the insight without some of the complex and damaging associations. Original sin is better understood as ‘estrangement from God.’ It is not an inherited condition starting in the Garden of Eden and passed on through sexual relations. Instead, it is a description of our human propensity to struggle with the good and our tendency to constantly opt for egoism and selfishness. And on the atonement, this is not an innocent life sacrificed to God to enable him to forgive sins, but rather a revelation of God whereby God enters the world of death to bring about the possibility of wholeness. Indeed, you insist that it is God who does the saving, not the cross as such.

You stress throughout that individual sainthood in this life is unlikely and very difficult. Paul’s rather compelling struggle with sin which is shared in Romans 7 is your key text. Paul knows what the good is but finds it difficult to live. This is, for you, why God is needed. God provides the resources to enable us to move slowly ever closer to the life that God intends for us.

Let us dig a little deeper here. John Wesley, the founder of Methodism, took the view that Christian perfection was possible. In his book A plain account of Christian perfection, he argues that through the processes of sanctification (where we are made holy) a Christian can avoid intentional sin because their hearts are so filled with love for God and their neighbor. Although mistakes (through ignorance) might still happen, unintentional sin, thanks to the ‘perfect love’ - a love focused on God and made possible by the Holy Spirit – the Christian is free from intentional sin.

One slight worry I have about the Episcopal Church (and I suspect liberal forms of Anglicanism generally) is that we are constantly so reassuring that God loves us and forgives us that we breed a form of discipleship which is very relaxed about sin. We give ourselves breaks all the time because we are so confident of the loving God that tolerates all our breaks.

John’s brother Charles was all much more nervous about such talk. For Charles Wesley, it is in the life to come that we can enjoy the perfected life. So, where are you on all this? Is it possible for a Christian to attain a life free from intentional sin? What is the role of the Church in cultivating such a life?
answer_text:
Christians are exhorted to become perfect. ‘Be perfect, therefore, as your heavenly Father is perfect’ (Matthew 5, 48).The Greek word translated as ‘perfect’ is ‘teleios’, which suggests something like ‘attaining your proper end or goal’(‘telos’).

There is not much problem about saying that God attains the goal of deity, for God is presumably always fully what God ought to be. With humans there is a problem. We are almost never what we could be or ought to be. Most of us do not even know what we ought to be, and many of us do not think there is anything we ought to be - we can be what we like, perhaps. Still, there is often a nagging feeling that we could have done better or that we have not lived up to our own ideals.

Believers in  God usually think that God sets ideals for us. In each situation, there are objectively better possible futures that are open. If these are real possibilities, then they really can be chosen. But humans often are not aware of what is best, or they opt for easier or more pleasant-seeming paths. Indeed, societies are so estranged from awareness of the Good that it is almost impossible for anyone learning their values and goals in such societies to completely achieve the personal goals that lie in their nature.

This sounds as if God makes demands on people that they mostly find impossible to obey. That seems very depressing, and it can lead to desperate and futile attempts to achieve the impossible, to feelings of personal failure and despair when they fail, or even to casting aside morality as impossible and irrelevant anyway. Some Christians, believing that God freely forgives, have thought that they could sin whenever they wished, since God would always forgive them. They failed to see that evil actions always bring harm on the agent, even though the divine intention is to bring them to repentance. Genuine repentance is necessary before forgiveness can take effect. And genuine repentance is not easy.

But the Christian life is not one of mournful penitence.  God does not make impossible demands. God does hold before people the ideal of perfect love for all, as something to be achieved not instantly but through a long process of growing co-operation with the divine Spirit.

It might be better to think of God not as demanding, and then as punishing for inevitable failure. Rather, think of God as inviting people to bring out the good that is in them, as ready to forgive the mistakes that will be made along the way, as promising that, despite all the appearances of failure and disaster in this estranged world, the good will be achieved, and that it will be in the best sense self-fulfilling, not simply self-denying.

Observing the world as it is, it would seem that for most people the personal achievement  of goodness, if it is to be achieved, would have to be beyond this life, and for many it would be a very long journey, which possibly might never  be completed. However, there are rare souls who seem to come near to alignment with the morally optimal possibilities of each situation (the ‘will of God,’ which is that we should always seek the good of others). For Christians, Jesus’ will was wholly aligned with the divine will, and that was because he was, in a unique way, filled with the divine Spirit. For many Christians other humans can realise such alignment. The  Roman Catholic church has defined that Mary, the mother of Jesus, was ‘immaculate’ - that is, free from sin or moral imperfection. And it is possible that other humans may achieve full alignment with the cosmic will for goodness.

Christians may suppose that this is because the divine Spirit acts in and through them, even if it is not explicitly recognised as such. For each person has a unique vocation and the perfection of love can be exhibited in many forms. For Christians Jesus, in his death and resurrection, will always be the definitive manifestation of the divine suffering and the archetype of personal immortality. But the divine Spirit works throughout the world, and may enable rare individuals to be perfect in love, even if they do not thereby become infallible or free from intellectual error.

In the Protestant world, John Wesley taught that moral perfection was possible for Christians, while Charles Wesley rather felt that it could only be achieved after death. There is no need to decide this issue. The important thought is that such complete alignment with the divine will is possible, though for most of us it still lies far ahead. We pray that we will be forgiven for our failures if we repent (and make reparations if possible). But we have the assurance that we will have the help of the divine Spirit to bring us closer to God. Christian life should therefore be marked, not by the gloom of self-flagellation or by extreme asceticism, but by trust in the power of God to make us whole, by hope for the final renewal of the human world, and by the joyful acceptance of the power of divine love working within us to transfigure our lives.

title: Question Twelve
choices: Worship must follow exact prescribed forms to be valid.
Worship is for human benefit - acknowledging our highest ideals and opening ourselves to transformation.
Worship is outdated ritual with no spiritual value.
Worship is primarily about giving God the praise God needs and deserves.
True worship is only private and individual, not communal.
hint_wrong: The answer emphasizes that worship benefits worshippers, not God - it's about acknowledging ideals and inviting transformation.
explanation_right: God needs no reassurance; worship is wholly for our sake - acknowledging our highest ideal and opening to its transforming power.
question_text:
Worship

When we started this conversation, we had three issues that shaped the worldview of our secular neighbor. The first was God, science, religious pluralism, and the problem of evil. There you combined an affirmation of the reality of God with a gentle epistemology that acknowledges the complexity of knowing and the possibility of learning from other faith trajectories. The second was the ethical life – how we know what is true in ethics and why, so often, it seems that the Church is not on the right side of certain moral questions. Your last answer touches on what it is to become a person living life aligned with the goals of the best life that the Divine Spirit has for us. It is a compelling vision.

The third issue our secular friend worried about is attending Church. Now like all human practices, there is a season is learning. A cricket match or the Oxford Debating Society are both complex occasions, which take considerable time to learn. There are elaborate practices and rituals present in these secular occasions. And church is the same. You do have to learn the symbolism before you appreciate a service. However, learning the symbolism of Church is difficult. For someone unfamiliar with church, a service is just incomprehensible – complex expectations in terms of body posture, clergy wearing strange outfits, and lots of strange sentiments that one is required to read and affirm from a book.

So, perhaps we could now turn to church. It was Rush Rhees who famously said, “If an Almighty Super Frankenstein told me to bow down and worship him or I will blast you to hell, I hope I would have the decency to say, ‘Go ahead and blast.’” So let us start with that basic religious practice. Worship. People go to Church to worship God. Early on in a Eucharistic service, we all read or sing the Gloria in Excelsis. “Glory to God in the highest, and peace to his people on earth. .... For you alone are the Holy One, you alone are the Lord.” Why does God need us to say all this? It sounds like flattery. It sounds like one of those Greco-Roman gods that needs to be constantly affirmed. Is God such a fragile ego that God needs all this reassurance that we think he is so great?
answer_text:
The first and most important thing I would say is that when people worship God it is not to make any difference to God. God needs no re-assurance and has no liking for flattery. It is wholly for their own sake. It is a bit like saying ‘This is my highest Ideal, and it is perfectly realised in the being that I love and would give up anything for’. Saying ‘Glory to God’ is not an attempt to add some glory to a narcissistic cosmic monarch. It is saying, ‘I give my allegiance to the personal source of the universe, and to seeking the flourishing of all the good that it intends’.

People may give their allegiance to many different things, and some of them are fairly terrifying. Human history is filled with people whose highest ideal is power, whose greatest goal is domination over others – their God is a savage God who demands blood and death.

We say that people worship money, and what we mean is that the love of money is what motivates all their actions. It matters what we worship, and ethical monotheism requires that what we worship should be love, compassion, and care. Such things as love and compassion do not just exist in some strange abstract space. They exist as dispositional properties of a personal being, and it is that being who is loved and worshipped. So ‘You alone are the Holy One’ declares that only these virtues are to be admired and realised in our lives.

This is the basic Judeo-Christian-Muslim belief – though it too can be perverted and become an intolerant and divisive worship of a savage and bloodthirsty God, the God of many of the early Hebrews, the Crusaders of Christianity, and the militant Jihadists of Islam.  It is such intolerance and divisiveness that people often see in religion. Unfortunately, they are right.

Yet that is what we should expect if we think that our world is estranged from God and under the power of greed and aggression. The Christian church  is an institution, or group of institutions, comprised of people who are devoted to Jesus as the Christ, the manifestation of the eternal Christ on earth. Yet it is not exempt from the corruptions of the estranged world. Ambition, envy, and aggression, can be found in the church as in every human institution. One of the pathologies of Christianity is to think that the church is a society of pure and perfect people,  or that it is easy to distinguish the good from the bad.

All are estranged; and all are called to perfection. No individuals can invent Christianity for themselves. It must be learned in a community, put into practice within a community, and supported by a community of fellow pilgrims. The church has a personal ideal of perfection in the life of Jesus, a pattern of self-giving in the death of Jesus, and a goal of transfiguration in the resurrection of Jesus. It also has, Christians believe, a present relation with the risen Jesus through its prayers and sacraments.

Yet the church is a human institution as well as a divine one. It calls sinners to participate as well as the respectable. It is a place where cosmic mind encounters and empowers human minds. Worship is the human response to the disclosure  of the ultimately real. The appropriate response  is one of awe (characterised as ‘fear’ in many Biblical texts), reverence, and philokalia (love of the good and beautiful).

The seemingly strange practices of many Christian churches, from ‘eating the body of Christ’ to speaking in tongues, are ways of forming this response in minds at many different stages of development and in many different cultures. The churches are societies of people who are morally and aesthetically diverse. They are parts of the estranged world, not exempt from it. But they speak of a world beyond and of an ultimate reality which breaks into this world and begins to transform the lives of those who are open to its call. In this sense, strange and even repulsive though they may sometimes seem, churches are communities where people learn to respond to the ultimately good and beautiful, and to participate in its presence and its power. They can be, and often are, sources of light in the darkness of an estranged world.

title: Question Thirteen
choices: Sacraments work automatically regardless of the recipient's disposition.
Sacraments are merely symbolic memorials with no spiritual reality.
Sacraments are temporal signs pointing to eternal spiritual realities - the Eternal Christ becomes present through them.
Only two sacraments (baptism and communion) are valid; others are human inventions.
Sacraments are unnecessary; only inner faith matters.
hint_wrong: The answer sees sacraments as genuine encounters with spiritual reality, not mere symbols or magic - temporal signs of eternal presence.
explanation_right: Sacraments are real encounters with the Eternal Christ through material signs - neither magic nor mere memory.
question_text:
– The sacraments

It is in Church, then, that we sit and acknowledge the source of everything as an ideal that we affirm and invite to shape our lives. All those hymns and prayers that sound like flattery should be seen as an invitation to recognize that God is the source of our values and the resource to enable those values to be realized in our lives. This is a beautiful vision of worship.

Now Christians disagree about many things. And one of them is the significance of the Eucharist, or, to be more precise, the bread and wine that become the Body and Blood of our Lord. Some, like our Baptist friends, make the Lord’s Supper a monthly occasion that supplements the preaching of the Word. The more liturgical traditions – the Roman Catholics, Orthodox, Lutherans, and Anglicans – make the Eucharist (or Mass) much more central.

Now our secular friends can understand the Baptist line. The bread and the wine are vehicles that enable us to remember the death of Jesus Christ. However, in the liturgical traditions – in the Anglican tradition of which we are a part – there is a really weird claim. These traditions claim that when Jesus said of the Bread – “this is my body” - and of the wine - “this is my blood” - he meant it literally. Somehow when a priest says The Great Thanksgiving, the bread and the wine become the body and blood of Jesus.

This does sound very odd. So, Jesus is on the cross two thousand years ago, there has been a billion Eucharists since then – does this body and blood fly from the past to the table? And if you put the bread and the wine under a microscope and compare the before the Great Thanksgiving and the after the Great Thanksgiving, it is still identical. The question is then: is there any way that this sacramental theology can be intelligible and plausible?

There is, of course, an extensive debate about the number of sacraments. Roman Catholics have seven – Baptism, Confirmation, Eucharist, Penance, Anointing of the Sick, Holy Orders, and Matrimony. Meanwhile the Lutherans and Anglicans tend to stress the two primary ones that Jesus affirmed – Baptism and the Eucharist. How many sacraments are there?

There is a trend among liberal Christians to say everything is sacramental (everything can be a vehicle of God’s grace – whatever that means). This means that a tree or a child’s birthday party or a book club or the view of the ocean can all be moments when you see God. Is this right?

Where do you stand on the sacraments?
answer_text:
Most Christian churches take the recorded life of Jesus in the Gospels to be a decisive revelation of the nature of God. This life had a more than historical significance. It was based on a series of historical events, but it pointed to a spiritual and eternal reality. It was a sacrament, a temporal event with an eternal meaning. That is what I think a sacrament is.

Yet Jesus, for his followers, did not only show what God was like. He conveyed something of the wisdom and love of God to them, as they were open to receive it. The extraordinary thing was that after he died, it seemed to them that he continued to do so, as in his risen transcendental form he conveyed a present and powerful spiritual force to them.

In succeeding ages the many societies of his followers, the churches, established rituals which formalized these experiences of discernment and empowerment. They became the Christian sacraments.

Different churches developed rather different theories and interpretations of the sacraments, but in almost all of them the leading idea was that through these rituals, Jesus Christ was known as a living presence and empowering spiritual force.

There can surely be countless temporal times and places where Spirit can be known and felt, and they are certainly not confined to churches. To some people the churches they have known would be the last places they would occur. Yet it is fitting that those who find Jesus to be their window into God and the source of their growth in the Spirit should look to the sacraments of their church for their spiritual growth.

As a priest of the Episcopal (Anglican) Church, I am aware that this church is just one small part of the Christian world, but I am fairly happy with our view, deriving from St. Augustine, that the two main sacraments which are recorded as originating with Jesus, are baptism and the Eucharist. The Eucharist can seem especially strange to non-Christians, with its talk of eating the body and drinking the blood of Jesus. But if you think of a sacrament as a temporal sign of an eternal truth, it will begin to make more sense.

Christians are not cannibals, and do not eat physical bodies. In the Eucharist they consume bread and wine. A ‘body’, in the broadest sense, is a physical object with a spatio-temporal location. The body of Christ, in one sense, is such an object which makes the spiritual reality of the eternal Christ accessible at that location. Of course, Christ is present everywhere, but that reality is rarely accessible to humans (it is not discerned or felt). In the person of Jesus, his followers believe, the nature of the eternal Christ was manifested in a decisive way.

In the Eucharist, when bread is consecrated it exists as a re-presentation (not a repetition) of this historical manifestation. For at the last supper with his disciples, Jesus made the sharing of bread ‘in memory of him’ a way of making his presence as disclosive of the eternal Word of God something continually available to the churches.

In its context, in a community of faith, consuming the bread is thus taking the reality of Christ into one’s own life. Bread becomes the ’body’, the  spatio-temporal location, of the eternal Christ as it was revealed in Jesus.

In a similar way, wine becomes the ’blood’, the life (in the Hebrew Bible, blood was thought to be the life of animals) of the risen Christ, received by the devotee in the context of reflecting on the life of Jesus and turning to Christ in prayer.

The physical elements of bread and wine do not change, but their meaning changes completely as they become the vehicles of the real presence and life of the Christ disclosed in Jesus. This should not be thought of as a matter of merely subjective feeling. It is the real imparting of the divine Spirit in  and with the physical elements of bread and wine.

This is my own view of how the Eucharist  can be a central part of Christian life. Most churches accept that Jesus did institute the celebration of a meal in memory of him, but some regard this solely as a memorial, and do not give the bread and wine special sacramental significance.

I have tried to give an account which is spiritually helpful of one central church sacrament, but I recognize that there are many other ways of receiving Christ or the Spirit into one’s life without employing such heavy symbolism. For them, perhaps the word ‘sacrament’ could be given a much broader meaning, and refer to any temporal event with spiritual significance. That would not be wrong, but the more specific idea of church sacraments, especially the Eucharist, has been important for most Christian traditions, and remains for many a central focus of their spiritual lives.

title: Question Fourteen
choices: Ministry is only about preaching, not sacraments.
Only ordained priests can validly perform sacraments through apostolic succession.
Anyone can do anything; no special ministry is needed.
Christ is the true minister of sacraments; human mediators serve this reality without exclusive claims.
Ordination confers indelible supernatural powers unavailable to laity.
hint_wrong: The answer emphasizes Christ as the true minister - human orders serve this without implying exclusive supernatural powers.
explanation_right: The validity of sacraments rests on Christ, not human ministers - though ordered ministry serves the community's worship.
question_text:
– Orders of Ministry

The beauty of your account of the sacraments is that you manage to affirm that the bread and the wine become more than just bread and wine without lapsing into some complex ‘magic’. The Eternal Christ is present in the consecrated bread and wine. The context in which we receive the bread and wine makes the moment holy. This all makes sense.

In the Anglican and Roman Catholic traditions, you need to be a priest to preside at the table (or should I say altar) and celebrate the Eucharist. And with this role comes a very fancy title. It started in the fifteenth century and became widespread in the seventeenth century, priests have been ‘revered’ - hence carry the title Reverend. Now I know a lot of priests (me included) who I don’t really think deserve to be revered. But part of the reason for the title is the claim that they are a vehicle that can mediate God’s grace in the Eucharist.

It is all linked to the claim that bishops who ordain priests are in apostolic succession. There is a link between Jesus and the apostles and the Bishop of Connecticut who ordained me a priest. For many lay Christians, this distinctive link with Jesus creates a capacity to confront evil (a demon perhaps) as well as create the gift of the sacrament of Holy Eucharist.

Now naturally, there is a threefold order of ministry in the liturgical traditions – Deacons who assist in service and liturgy; priests (perhaps presbyter is better) leads the congregation and administers sacrament; and the bishops who ordain clergy and provide doctrinal leadership. Some traditions (such as the Anglican Church) permit women to serve as priests and bishops. Others do not.

These roles in the church come with some very strange outfits. A clerical collar (which again has its origins in the 15th to the 17th century but became the norm relatively recently in 1865 and Roman Catholic priests in the United States were required to wear the collar in 1884) is part of a priest’s attire. Then so many vestments are hang-overs from the Greco-Roman world – the Alb (the white linen tunic) and the chasuble – were developed in the sixth century; and we are still wearing them. Why?

So, my question is this: what account would you give of the threefold orders of ministry? Do you believe in the apostolic succession? How do you feel about being a reverend? And do we need all these funny clothes?
answer_text:
Now you are asking me to leave the realms of theology and get into the realm of politics and authority in the churches. I confess I am a little uncomfortable here, given my general view that all human institutions are corruptible. There is going to be no perfect or ideal institution. The checkered history of the churches confirms this judgment, as the degree of corruption, division, immorality and hatred that many churches have displayed is depressing in the extreme.

I was baptized and confirmed in the Church in Wales, a small Episcopal self-governing national church which makes no claim to be the one true church, disagrees with the Roman Catholic and Orthodox churches by ordaining women as priests, and is hospitable to many varieties of Christian belief. I am reasonably happy with that, since it is also a member of a world-wide Episcopal federation of churches, so not too nationalistic, and I like to draw the limits of acceptable Christian belief as broadly as possible.

The issue of women priests and of Bishops is a very divisive one at present. The Roman Catholic church holds that only priests have authority to forgive sins and to celebrate the Eucharist, and when they do, they stand in the place of Christ, something which women cannot do. Furthermore, there needs to be a continuous line of Bishops from the 12 apostles with the authority to ordain men as priests (the apostolic succession).

I am not persuaded of these points, though I accept that many Christians are, and this will prevent any full unity of Christian churches, though it should not lead to hostility between them. My view is that Christ is the one who makes the sacrament valid. The human celebrant is the mediator, not the incarnation, of Christ. The celebrant's sex does not matter, as women are fully human.  And I think it is fidelity to the gospel that is passed from the 12 apostles to present day Bishops (senior leaders), not any physical succession in office. It may seem a pity that this cuts me off from complete union with so many fellow Christians. But then such diversity is natural, and it may even be a good thing that freedom of belief should be welcomed and can lead to friendship without insistence on complete agreement. Maybe that is a lesson Christians, and many religious people, have yet fully to learn.

As for all the funny clothes and so on, I do quite like many old traditions, though it is surprising how relatively recent ‘old traditions’ can be (they are usually only from 5 to 500 years old). Given my acceptance of human depravity, I recognize that my membership would make any church less than perfect, but I do believe that Jesus’ ‘sermon on the mount’ (Matthew 5 – 7) is a permanent reminder of what a church should be. So, I like diverse traditions, but think they should all be aware that they are one among many interpretations of faith. Some unfortunately should be opposed, when they promote violence or harm. But change is always possible, and there can often be much to learn from traditions other than one’s own. There is no fixed formula determining how one should view diverse traditions, but reference to the sermon on the mount should influence one’s attitude in particular cases.

I do support the ecumenical movement, which encourages friendship and dialogue between different Chistian churches. I would welcome some form of formal union between Christian groups. But I am very conscious of deeply held issues which at present divide churches. For that reason I would stress the importance of supporting conscientious freedom of belief and tolerance of diversity, while opposing groups which encourage violence or hatred.

To answer your questions, I think the division of Christian ministry into deacons, priests, and bishops, is a natural and understandable historical development. But it is not the only possible or Biblically authorised system, and it needs to be protected against authoritarian and paternalistic tendencies. I do not mind being reverend ( not ‘very reverend’ like you) and wearing funny clothes, but I do think we should all accept Jesus’ teaching that ‘he that would be great among you must be your servant’ (Matthew 20, 26), and that reverends and very reverends should start making the coffee for parish meetings, and washing their own funny clothes. Somehow, I cannot see that happening, so we all have to live with compromises – but at least we should see what we are doing.

title: Question Fifteen
choices: The Church has infallible teaching authority that cannot err on doctrine.
Doctrinal boundaries are oppressive and should be abolished entirely.
All doctrine is equally essential; any deviation is heresy.
Heresy is merely difference of opinion that should be tolerated.
The Church must safeguard the core gospel (Jesus as forgiver and life-giver) while allowing theological diversity on secondary matters.
hint_wrong: The answer distinguishes essential gospel (Jesus as liberator and life-giver) from secondary theological elaborations.
explanation_right: Fidelity to the gospel core is essential; but much theological elaboration is secondary and admits diversity.
question_text:
– Church and Heresy

The idea that it is the validity of the sacrament is Christ and that any human can be a mediator of the sacrament is powerful. And once again you simplify matters considerably when you insist that the key idea that the Church must safeguard is “fidelity to the gospel” - this needs to be effectively passed down from the apostles to our current Bishops. In The New Apologetics, I argued for a more robust account of the apostolic succession, although I confess, I am not sure that I still believe that.

But this might be a good segue to my next question. For you, one of the attractions of the Church of Wales is that you like “to draw the limits of acceptable Christian belief as broadly as possible.” Simultaneously, you do want the Church to ensure “fidelity to the gospel” over the centuries. How do you relate these two aspirations? The first would imply considerable openness; and the second would imply a firm boundary.

Traditionally, the Church has been very concerned about heretics. Irenaeus in 180 CE wrote Against Heresies. It was partly a concern about the unity of the Church, but it was also a concern about fidelity to the Gospel. When the Ecumenical Councils gathered, they wanted to safeguard certain crucial claims about Jesus – Jesus really was fully God and fully human, Jesus was a disclosure of the Eternal Word and the Eternal Word was the Second Person of the Trinity, and that Jesus really does save humanity on the cross.

In your writings, you took on Don Cupitt – a priest who argued for a non-realist account of the faith (a faith without an objective God but instead a God of moral aspiration). You have defended a robust account of the Incarnation, where Jesus is identical with God, against the theological pluralist John Hick.

Simultaneously, you have described yourself as very sympathetic to the Hindu philosopher Ramanuja’s Vishishtadvaita Vedanta - his qualified non-dualism. Is there is a sense in which you are a Christian Hindu? And if so, is this compatible with being a priest in the Church of England?

So, where should the Church draw a line? Is the concept of heresy still intelligible? Are there views that cannot be tolerated in the Church?
answer_text:
When I say that I desire fidelity to the Gospel among leaders of the churches, I mean by Gospel the proclamation of Jesus as the forgiver of sin and the giver of new life in the Spirit. Jesus is the Messiah, the liberator and life-giver of humanity.

That is a simple gospel, and people like me (theologians) will want to spell it out further. History shows that there are many ways of doing this, many of them fantastic, many appealing, none of them wholly adequate. We get various definitions of the incarnation, atonement, the Triune nature of God, and the afterlife which differ considerably. Meetings of church leaders (some grandly called ecumenical councils, though there are even arguments about which these were) have argued about these, and often voted on which they preferred. Political and national factors have strongly influenced them, and eventually churches split into Roman Catholic, Orthodox, Protestant, and many smaller groups, because they could not agree. Each of them accused the others of heresy, by which they meant that only their own church had the right view. It is natural to think one is right, but it is not natural to think that one’s own view is identical with God’s, especially when it was arrived at after so much bad-tempered and sometimes violent argument.

What I would prefer to stress is that God’s revelation is not doctrinal; it is existential. Those who became the first disciples did not assent to a raft of doctrines. They encountered Jesus as one who gave a new and demanding interpretation of Torah, who warned of divine judgment on evil, but who proclaimed that the Kingdom of God had come near, and eternal life with God was promised for all who trusted in God. They received from Jesus forgiveness of past sins, a vision and a power of new life, and a promise of personal fulfilment in union with God. This is still the heart of Christian faith, the Gospel which has been handed down from the first apostles, so that people can still encounter the risen Jesus, and be inspired by his Spirit, which is the Spirit of God.

Of course there are doctrines here, but they need to be worked out more fully with reference to our other knowledge of the world and in relation to other religious traditions, especially to Judaism, the mother of Christianity. Those who are blessed (or cursed) with intellectual curiosity will face a raft of questions about the exact relation of Jesus and the church to Torah, how and when the divine judgment will be carried out, what the Kingdom of God is, and what the afterlife will be like. None of these things is clearly stated in Scripture or anywhere else. They are matters of theological interpretation, subject to all the vagaries and limitations of human thought. There will be authorities to guide us, but who will those authorities be? For many, they will be the church leaders (the magisterium, for Roman Catholics). For some others, it will be the Bible (but there are many different interpretations of the Bible, as is shown by the large number of Protestant churches). I myself  think it would be wise to consult scholars who have spent their lives studying the Scriptures, scholars of the history of religious traditions, and those generally considered to be outstanding doctrinal theologians. But then I am a doctrinal scholar, so I would think that – and I also know how argumentative scholars can be. But I still think we should consult them. I do not think it is wise to regard any of them as inerrant. I understand that many want a stronger view of authority than this, something infallible or protected from error. But I think there are too many opposing views from intelligent and well-informed people for this to be plausible. It seems arbitrary to take one view as certain when it is opposed by so many informed and conscientious people

What then is to be done? We just have to start from where we are; then, if we can, research as widely and deeply as is possible for us, both views similar to ours and those which are very different; and then decide either to stay with where we are, or to modify our beliefs without fundamentally abandoning them, or, in extreme cases, to change even the core of our learned beliefs. We cannot evade the fact that we do have to decide, even if it seems to us that it is not so much a personal decision as a simple response to truth. Whatever we do, God will, I believe, accept those who honestly seek truth, even if they turn out to be wrong. That is why I think it is immoral to persecute heretics.

The fact is that none of us starts with a blank sheet. All of us grow up with a set of beliefs and values that we have learned from others. The philosopher Immanuel Kant stated one view of the European Enlightenment by saying, ‘Think for yourself’. But that ignores the extent to which we are all shaped by the communities we live in, which have taught us our basic values and outlooks. For many, that will determine their beliefs. For others, new knowledge (like the theory of evolution), new moral values (like the full equality of the sexes), and new information (like better understanding of other cultures and ideologies) will modify accepted views, and sometimes change them radically.

At this point I should advert to my own position. I was born into a very secular culture, where religion was not considered important. But I joined Protestant Christian groups, singing in church choirs for example. There were different Protestant churches around me, so I knew that I was associated with a small minority (Episcopalians or Anglicans) within a larger minority (Christians) in a culture that contained a diversity of views, but that on the whole was democratic and not religiously based (despite the fact that the Church of England is vanishingly ‘established’ as the national faith).

Starting from this base, it is hard for me to think of one supreme authority in religion which alone knows the absolute truth. It looks obvious that there are lots of different views on almost every topic, and that what became Christian orthodoxy was often the result of hard fought debates, not of simply recording what all Christians had always agreed on.

The churches I knew very often accepted the ancient ‘orthodox’ conclusions, though with various qualifications. So they got general agreement on the Nicene Creed, for example, but  certainly not on the Athanasian Creed. And after the Protestant Reformation they disagreed with most Roman Catholic decisions, especially Papal infallibility and the idea of church authority as embodied in a male hierarchy.

So in the churches I was associated with, the idea of heresy gradually disappeared, and was replaced by an acceptance of diversity of interpretation. Of course, there are crazy and dangerous interpretations, and some that should be opposed because they are harmful or commend hatred. But often there can be much to learn from other traditions. I have learned much from the Indian tradition of vishist-advaita, and have sometimes called myself an Advaitan Christian. I believe the time has come when spiritual insights can be drawn from many religious traditions. After all, if God is concerned for the salvation of all, God will have revealed something of the divine nature and purpose in every human culture. It will enrich many Christian traditions of theological interpretation to affirm this.

This is a global ecumenism, though for many it will be enough just to establish good relations others in their locality. Christians can accept a division between the Gospel proclamation and later theological interpretations, and so draw the boundaries of Christian belief as broadly as possible, yet remain true to the basic Gospel of divine forgiveness and eternal life in God through Jesus Christ.

title: Question Sixteen
choices: Doubt is a valuable tool for testing beliefs - subjective commitment can coexist with objective uncertainty.
True faith eliminates all possibility of doubt.
Doubt and faith are completely incompatible.
Doubt is sinful and should be suppressed through stronger faith.
Doubt proves religious claims are false and should lead to abandonment of faith.
hint_wrong: The answer sees doubt as a philosophical tool for testing truth, compatible with subjective certainty and commitment.
explanation_right: Doubt tests beliefs constructively; one can have subjective certainty and commitment while acknowledging objective uncertainty.
question_text:
– Doubt and Experience

It is interesting to watch how you weave the sociological reality of one’s own location (a protestant in an increasingly secular country, aware of how different cultures shape us all) with a humility about your understanding of the truth. You also stress that the heart of faith is not so much a rational claim about the nature of the world (although you have already made it clear that materialism is – intellectually – a highly improbably worldview), but more an existential encounter with the promise of forgiveness in Christ.

So, let us explore the concept of doubt for a moment. In question three we touched on the challenge of staking your life on an intellectual hypothesis. There you anticipated your emphasis here on the centrality of experience and the complex relationship of the lived experience and intellectual reflection. The experience gives us conviction; the reflection gives us humility.

This does raise the issue of the vagaries of experience. On the one hand, we have Michael Goulder who after forty years in the priesthood finally acknowledges that he never had an experience of God. (See John Hick and Michael Goulder, Why Believe in God?). And on the other hand, we have Mother Teresa who lost her experience of God. Her private letters document her pain. She writes, “Please pray for me, that it may please God to lift this darkness from my soul for only a few days. For sometimes the agony of desolation is so great and at the same time the longing for the Absent One so deep, that the only prayer which I can still say is – Sacred Heart of Jesus I trust in Thee – I will satiate They thirst for souls.” (Mother Teresa, Come Be My Light, Chapter 8). Her only certainty was her sense of vocation and the obligation to serve the poor.

My question is this: does the reflection, which is aware of the complexity of knowing about God, ever undermine or create doubt for you in the legitimacy of the experience? We are having this exchange as we both age and are conscious of our mortality. Do you ever find yourself doubting life beyond the grave? Do you ever find yourself thinking that perhaps Jesus was not the Incarnate Word but just another first century apocalyptic prophet?  Or perhaps the doubt in Christianity takes the form of thinking that perhaps another religious tradition has more truth. Perhaps the Hindu claim of reincarnation is more plausible than a different space-time universe called heaven? And finally, if experience is so central, then why is it so often denied to the person who prays fervently for the gift of a sense of God?
answer_text:
Doubt is a major tool of philosophical enquiry. It is a way of testing the truth of beliefs. It does not aim at objective certainty, which is rarely obtainable. Objective certainty is such that all informed and intelligent persons would agree on a truth claim. Subjective certainty is when a person feels sure of a truth, but some equally informed and intelligent persons do not agree. In matters of morality, philosophy, the arts and religion, objective certainty can never be achieved. But subjective certainty is widespread.

On some matters, subjective certainty is compatible with and even demands absolute commitment. For instance, you may not be sure you can swim well, but you may be certain you should dive into the sea to save your child, and you may do so, ignoring your doubt.

In morality, you may be certain that you should care for a disabled person, though many others would not only doubt that, but would avoid helping.

In music, you may devote your life to studying Wagner, though others may find him boring and long-winded.

In philosophy, you may be certain that Idealism is true, while your friends regard it as confused and mistaken.

In religion, you may commit your life to following Jesus, even though you know some others think he was a deluded prophet. This could be because you believe there is a God, who speaks through prophets and sages; or because you believe that the demands of moral goodness are rooted in some objectively existing being.  It could be because you accept Jesus as the, or at least a, human image of God; that  you trust the testimony of the apostles to his resurrection, that you are impressed by the reported experiences of the risen Jesus by wise and good people; or that  you  think trusting in Jesus as the Christ has forgiven your past sins, and given your life more meaning and hope.

All these things, and many others, are inter-connected. None of them stand alone as the basis of all the others. They form a closely formed web of beliefs, some central and some more peripheral, but all supporting and supported by the others. In this complex web, beliefs near the centre are more firmly fixed and their removal would affect or undermine many other beliefs. For instance, removing belief in God would, for most people, remove most other Christian beliefs. Whereas removing a belief on the periphery might have less effect on the others. Changing your mind about women being priests might have few effects on your other beliefs, though it probably would have some, and for some people they would be very important.

Everything that gives only subjective certainty is in principle subject to doubt. However, all the factors mentioned can make what may otherwise seem a purely subjective certainty into a basis for an absolute commitment.

Most importantly, Christian faith is a gospel, the proclamation of the Lordship of Christ. This is the proclamation that the old age of Temple sacrifices by the Jewish priesthood was coming to an end, and a new age in which the Spirit of Christ can be felt in the hearts of humans everywhere has begun. The Lordship of Christ, the ‘coming near’ of the Kingdom of God, has ushered in an age that promises liberation from the forces of hatred, greed and pride that have estranged the human world from God.

This is not a matter of just having some pure religious experience. It already presupposes a general acceptance of the prophetic and priestly history of Israel, and an expectation of a Messianic renewal in Israel. It also supposes belief that Jesus died and rose from death. It is not just a matter of subjective experience, but entails belief in historical facts. Such beliefs are always subject to sceptical doubt.

But faith is not just assent to historical facts. It is responding positively to what is felt to be God’s call. For those who hear it, the call is insistent and demanding. It is like the call of morality which comes in the midst of a world of injustice and untruth. But it is a more personal call. It does not just say ‘You must do this’. It says ‘I am the one who chooses you to be with me’.

In Christianity, this call can evoke a  committal of life to Jesus Christ, taking him to be the human image of God, following his teaching, affirming his risen presence, and accepting the working of his spirit in the heart. This is an absolute commitment,  even though it is based on a subjective certainty.

The churches have a gospel to proclaim, that God offers forgiveness and new life to all through Jesus Christ. Theologians work out the presuppositions and implications of this gospel. There is a broad agreement on many of these, but there are also quite a few disagreements (compare Tridentine Catholicism with German liberal Protestantism), and of course social and scientific changes force various restatements of them. It is in this area of working out the presuppositions and implications of the gospel, that the believer can legitimately express doubts and explore new possibilities.

An informed believer should allow for doubt and diversity, allowing that people can be subjectively certain of different and sometimes conflicting beliefs. One cannot help what one believes to be true, as long as one has investigated as widely and deeply as one can. Yet Christians, who have once made an absolute commitment to what they believe to be the call of God, will naturally try to make this central to their conceptual web.

There have been times when doubt was regarded as sin. That is only possible when there is some clear authority that could lay down truths that were objectively certain. If this is thought to be not the case,  all is subject to rational doubt.

The fact that you have made an absolute commitment is a very strong reason countering doubts which may arise. But it is not irrevocable, and could be outweighed by strong enough considerations. Throughout my academic career I have taught philosophy, and it has led me to see  that intelligent people can hold their views strongly while calmly accepting that many others disagree. In theology I think it would be healthy for the same thing to be accepted. As long as people honestly seek truth, God will accept them.  So I think that churches should be hospitable to such seekers. That  is what I mean by setting the bounds of belief as broadly as possible.

Nevertheless, once an absolute commitment has been made, it is reasonable to seek views which support it, and there is a probability, not a certainty,  that doubts can be resolved, even if one cannot see how. It is possible to be absolutely committed while living with doubts and indecisions.

Nor does absolute commitment necessarily involve a spectacular vision or emotional event, though especially in the case of prophets and sages, it may do. As in morality, the ‘call of duty’ may be the occurrence of a strong belief that one should act in a specific way, without any emotional content. So in religion the ‘call of God’ may be the occurrence of a belief that one should trust and obey God, without any special feeling occurring.

When people say they have no ‘experience’ of God, they are perhaps thinking of God as a person who would be known to them as a loving presence. Yet the idea of God as a person whose presence evokes a response of loving devotion is only one way in which God is known.

Such experiences are of enormous value, and the Hebrew prophets, Christian saints and individuals in other religions too have them, but they do not occur to everyone. Some other main ways of religious experiencing are the unitive way, where the self is felt to be absorbed in an ineffable and all-including and blissful reality; the moral way, finding oneself irresistibly attracted by ideals of goodness and supreme value; and  the aesthetic way, where nature, music, art, or literature speak of a transcendent depth mediated through finite forms. They can all be seen as genuine experiences of God.

I have no idea why some people would lack a sense of a devotional presence, except to say that such is not their gift. People differ widely, and some undoubtedly will have gifts that many others lack. I believe that honest doubts are part of a positive search for truth, and that in the end God will accept all who desire the divine presence when it becomes clear to them.

title: Question Seventeen
