explanation_right: Divine encounter often comes through quiet perception of calling, moral demand, and empowering presence rather than dramatic visions.
question_text:
– Experience of God:

Your shift of emphasis from earlier answers is striking. You now invite us to see a worldview as an interwoven network of beliefs, some lying at the core—such as belief in God—calling for deeper commitment, while others rest nearer the periphery and invite less. Doubt plays an important role here, serving as a mechanism of reflection. And you remind us that God always honors the sincere search for truth. I find this very compelling.

The emphasis on experience also remains central. You note three ways in which a person might encounter God: the unitive way, where the self feels absorbed into the divine; the moral way, where ideals of goodness and supreme value take precedence; and the aesthetic way, where nature, music, art, or literature participate in the transcendence.

But here our secular neighbors are puzzled. With the moral and aesthetic ways, they wonder: why call these experiences of God at all? Moral obligation, after all, can be understood universally—many feel compelled to feed the poor or work for justice without reference to faith. Mother Teresa herself distinguished between her call to serve and her experience of God. Likewise, appreciation of beauty—whether in Mozart’s music, a painting, or a mountain landscape—might be seen simply as recognition of human genius or natural wonder. Why, then, interpret such experiences as encounters with God?

It is the first path—the unitive—that seems most distinctly religious. And again, secular friends are curious. What exactly is this? Among evangelicals, this often takes the form of a relationship with Jesus, personal and conversational, as if an invisible companion walked with them each day. In more catholic traditions, the sacraments take center stage: the bread is truly the body of Christ, and in receiving it one is drawn into awe and reverence. Mystics such as Julian of Norwich or John of the Cross describe still deeper experiences—intense, dramatic, and overwhelming. Are all these parts of your category of unitive experiences?

So let us probe further. Why speak of morality and music as experiences of God? And in the unitive category, clearly religious in character, what is actually happening? What does it feel like to undergo a unitive encounter with the divine?
answer_text:
If there is a God, who is of ultimate value, power, and wisdom, then there will be a purpose of great value in any created world. When intelligent beings exist, they will wish to pursue that purpose and its values. There will be a perception of objective demands and possibilities,  perhaps a sense of empowerment, and certainly hope for realization of a moral purpose.

Among values, the creation and appreciation of beauty will be important, and this can be seen as participation in the creative work of a higher power. A sense of sharing in a higher force of creativity and of divine inspiration and co-creation will often be found.

This does not entail any explicit reference to God. Indeed great artists often reject any idea of  God. But I think this is because their idea of God may be of an interfering tyrant or an enemy of free thought. If it is recognized that God is  one who empowers creativity and inspires originality  then such empowerment and inspiration can be seen as a form of knowledge of and interaction with God. It is not that we have to make an insecure inference from some scenic beauty to an invisible designing God. Rather, we see the scene itself as an expression of God’s being and value, realized in this particular occasion.

Scientific discovery can also be seen as coming to understand the rationality of the cosmos as a complex and highly integrated structure  fitted to produce finite minds. It will have mathematical elegance and an apparent tendency towards self-understanding and self-direction. Again, some scientists  will reject any idea of a god who reveals on authority beliefs which contradict the findings of modern cosmology and evolution.  But many scientists regard the cosmos with awe and wonder. These are appropriate responses to the God who manifests in the splendour of the galaxies and  the  intricasies of the genetic code.  They also  are forms of knowledge of the cosmos and of the underlying source of the cosmos, the ultimate reality of God.

Perhaps the most important manifestation of God is the sense of moral obligation, which overrides or ought to override all other mental incentives to action. Those who are aware of the force of moral ideals and obligations, and of the future  possibilities of new forms of value, experience them as objectively existing aspects of being which are not simply preferences humans happen to have. The sense of obligation can be perverted to become a matter of  pathological compulsions or unquestioning submission to some destructive authority. Yet in its true form its authority is that of the good and of the wellbeing of the world. This may seem to some to be independent of the dictates of any God. But in fact it is identical to the knowledge of God as the source of all genuine human ideals,  obligations, and purposes.

Morality, art, and science can and do exist without knowledge of God. But when they are seen as responses to aspects of objective reality and as they are seen together, they will be forms of knowing God. For these are the ways in which the deepest aspects of reality can be known, in its beauty, its rationality, and its goodness.

There is another aspect of human experience which is important in building up an idea of God. It is found in almost all societies, though it is by no means shared by all individuals. This is a claim to direct experience of God.

There are some humans who have intense experiences of a reality which seems to exist beyond all finite objects and is of supreme value. These experiences vary in detail.   Some seem to experience an inexpressible unity in which all limits of time, space, and individuality fade away. Even the sense of being a distinct ego fades as they feel part of one all-encompassing unity of being. They find an impersonal and unchanging beauty that transcends all things finite and perishing. Others, with different temperaments and cultural backgrounds, may find a personal presence which embraces them in love.

However, most of them stress that they cannot adequately describe the object of their experience. They feel that they have touched or felt a reality which is ultimately real. This suggests that they have known different aspects of that which cannot be finally described by any single set of human concepts, but which seems to be of great value, and to transcend and underlie the finite world. The sense of impersonal union and the sense of personal devotion are not contradictory but complementary ways of describing that which is literally inexpressible.

Jesus, as recorded in John’s Gospel especially, experienced a sense of unity and also a loving relationship, with the one he called ‘Father’. For his present-day disciples this establishes the idea of one loving, wise, and redeeming God, the fulfilment of the long tradition of Jewish prophetic thought and experience.

Christians find echoes of this experience of God in their lives, but few have intense feelings, either unitive or devotional. The experiences they have depend largely on their personalities and circumstances. But once they have a background belief in God, they are able to see many finite things as manifestations of God. That is how morality, art, nature, and science, can be seen and felt as expressions or mediators of a higher power and value.

Those who believe in God can find in morality, the sciences, and the arts, genuine ways of knowing God directly. They will think, I believe rightly, that God speaks through such finite phenomena. A unitive encounter with the divine is rare; the sense of being one with, or part of, God is liable to be dangerously mistaken. Yet rare individuals will experience this state during life, and it is an important confirmation of faith. It is also a foretaste of what, in the Scriptures, is promised to all who trust in God and Christ, however soon or late. As the Christian Scriptures say, now we see ‘through a glass darkly’, then we shall see ‘face to face’ (1 Corinthians 13, 12).

title: Question Eighteen
choices: Vocation is only for clergy and religious professionals.
Vocation means obeying specific divine commands heard audibly.
Vocation is God's communication of values and purposes we should pursue - discerned through conscience and community.
There is no divine calling; we simply choose our own paths.
Everyone has the same vocation; individual callings don't exist.

question_text:
– Vocation

You are clear that morality, art, and science can exist without God, thereby respecting the experience of our secular friends. Yet you argue that belief has the advantage of providing an interpretative frame—one that sees these realities as pointers to the Divine Mind underpinning all that is. You tread carefully around the unitive experience of God, emphasizing that most people do not encounter such intensity. It is a rare saint who enjoys that experience on this side of glory. You then conclude that “experience” for most Christians is much more ordinary, found in moments of calling, vocation, inspiration, and insight.

Let us stay in this place a little longer. The purpose of this exchange in the book is to explain the faith to our secular neighbor who finds it implausible, even unintelligible. For such a person, it is easy to grasp the experience of someone who finds Yo-Yo Ma’s performance of Bach’s Cello Suite No. 1 in G Major, Prelude utterly stunning. And yes, our secular neighbor can follow your claim that such beauty may point, in some sense, to a transcendent Mind who created all that is. At this step, your response remains intelligible to them.

Yet it now feels as though you have narrowed the intense experiences of the divine to only a very small number of saints. The ordinary believer, you suggest, experiences God in moments of calling and vocation. Here, however, our secular friend hesitates. In the Bible, God converses directly with Moses through a burning bush, calling him to stand on holy ground and to free God’s people from slavery in Egypt (Exodus 3). Is this the sort of experience you mean? Does God actually speak to the believer and tell them what to do? Is this what you intend by the experience of God through calling and vocation?

Another difficulty for our secular neighbor is that this sense of vocation can sometimes be destructive. When Mohamed Atta hijacked Flight 93 and flew the plane into the World Trade Center on 9/11, he almost certainly acted out of a sense of vocation, likely crying “Allahu Akbar” just before impact. He gave his life for his conviction that God had commanded him to attack the United States.

So, the question remains: if dramatic experiences of God are rare, and if most believers encounter God through a sense of vocation, what exactly does this feel like? How does a believer know that such an experience is truly of God, and not simply a misguided aspiration shaped by the intensity of their religious culture?
answer_text:
If there is a God, a conscious mind-like creator of the universe, it is very likely that God would inform created persons of the values and purposes they should pursue and the ultimate meaning of their lives.

Even if so much could be agreed, at this point human opinions begin to differ. Many think that God would dictate words to chosen individuals. Others think that God would influence chosen minds to have insights into values and purposes, without actually dictating exact words. In this case human wisdom would be attracted towards possible ideas by God, but the strength and character of that attraction would depend on the social and psychological factors present in the human situation. This is the view I hold.

The best place to start understanding this is to think about inspiration. It is not unusual for poets and prophets or holy persons to claim that they have been inspired or led to new ideas by some Muse or source beyond their conscious selves.

Shamans in tribal societies, sages in Asian societies, and prophets in Middle Eastern lands, all claim to have messages from the Spirit world, or to discern the Way of Heaven, or to hear the ‘word of the Lord’. In all these cases individuals who are set apart by their extraordinary gifts claim to have revelations of truth. There are many fakes and misleading claims made, and there are many conflicting ‘revelations’ among the world religions. This is not surprising, given the malign nature of humans, and the very different developing histories of human cultures.

There are two types of problems here, the possibility of fake claims, and the conflicts of claims to revelation. With regard to the former, there are ways of detecting fakes. The claimant to revelation must be honest and trustworthy, must show outstanding wisdom, and must be judged mentally well-balanced, not neurotic or psychopathic. This is always a matter of personal judgment, and people are often gullible or neurotic, but at least there are tests of moral excellence, wisdom, and psychological well-being, that can be applied. There are many claimants to have been inspired by higher spiritual powers who seem to pass these tests. But they still often seem to conflict in what they say. This is the second type of problem.

One way to approach this is to recognize that alleged revelations occur within developing traditions of thought. For instance, Buddhist revelations (as in the Lotus Sutra, for example) presume ideas of rebirth and the unsatisfactory nature of existence as a self. Christian revelations (in the Bible) presume the existence of a personal creator and the resurrection to eternal life of individual selves. Muslim revelations (in the Qu’ran) presume that revelation is in the exact words of God, and that those who fight in the way of God go to Paradise.

These clearly differ, and there are many other revealed traditions in the world, so there are many different claimed revelations. It does not at first seem that God would inspire all these conflicting views. However, if inspiration is seen as God influencing ideas which have a social and personal context, then one might expect that God would work with many different ideas, and that they could all develop from diverse origins towards a fuller, but still culturally influenced, understanding.

The idea of inspiration can be seen in many areas of human life, not only in religion. Even In many natural sciences, though God is rarely appealed to, there can be a development of ideas from rather crude and general conjectures to mathematically precise and testable theories. Some ideas come as sudden insights, eureka moments. They can seem like inspirations.

In the creative arts, some speak of inspiration when a poet seems to be taken over by a force beyond the conscious self and feels that he or she becomes the medium of ideas and words that almost write themselves.

In morality, an ethic of honour and revenge killings can develop slowly and unevenly to one of kindness and forgiveness. New values become apparent, with demanding power, and they can redirect and control one’s life.  Yet not all would think such things an improvement, and the primary axiom of such development – ‘treat others as you would wish to be treated’ – is an unprovable conjecture, even though it can seem to be obvious to some.

So in religion we might expect a development from something like fear of the anger of the gods to ethical monotheism (where theism may be understood as referring to whatever is taken to be of ultimate reality and value).

In each case, inspiration is an extension of an original insight or normative idea, which is in the repertoire of possibilities open in a given situation. It may then be accepted, ignored, resisted, or even misunderstood.

Thinking along these lines, one could see Christian thought as moving over the centuries from tribal polytheism towards the idea of one God as universally loving, who makes resurrection to eternal life open to all.

Then a Christian could see God (conceived by some Buddhists as ultimate mind or maybe as  a Bodhisattva) attracting Buddhist practitioners to see rebirth as a form of evolution (or devolution) in an afterlife, negation of self as an invitation to altruism, and nirvana as an indescribable goal of wisdom and bliss. This would still differ from Christianity, but it would be an intelligible way of seeing how God (conceived from a broadly Christian point of view) could be revealing important truths about the afterlife, self-sacrifice, and the ultimate goal of life.

Similarly, a Christian could see Islam as moving from the exclusive faith of a tribal society to an inclusive ethical theism for all humanity, and to an interpretation of jihad (struggle) as endeavour in prayer and compassion.

These interpretations show how God could influence very different traditions of thought, so that they develop towards more universalist and liberal forms. Of course, I have written from within a particular universalist and liberal Christian context. Others would provide their own views, from their own viewpoint.

There are many individual decisions to be made. Is personal immortality to be desired, or to be transcended? Is the ultimate reality personal or impersonal? Can there be holy wars, or is violence forbidden? Is religion a matter of keeping laws, or does it advocate personal freedom? Such questions, where choice between traditions is realistic, have to be answered by each individual, and they will determine which claimed revelation one might be inclined to accept. The revealed tradition will then become a way of relation to God (in Christianity) and to growth in the spiritual life.

There is in the Bible a development of revelatory experiences from Abram’s call to leave Ur, to Moses’ many revelations, accompanied by miracles. Then arise the prophets of Judaism, judging the leaders of Israel and Judah and proclaiming the need for repentance and a future of justice and peace. For Christians, this culminates in Jesus’ life, his teaching of the Kingdom of God, his miraculous healings and his resurrection. It is clear that these experiences are given to prophetic figures, are most often heard in verbal form, spoken or written while inspired by a higher power, and are accompanied by extraordinary expressions of God’s power.

It is in this way that Christian faith depends upon special revelatory experiences, which must be taken on trust by believers. The experiences of most believers are not so dramatic. They will probably be conditioned by prayerful reflection on a revealed tradition.

In a world of many claimed revelations, one, or perhaps more than one, may well appeal to an individual. Immersion in a revelatory tradition will give a way of living in the world which will promote specific values and purposes. Christians will see their lives in terms of rigorous moral demands and ideals, yet with the possibility of repentance and forgiveness for failure.  They will, or should, feel called to increase the well-being of persons and care for their environment. They will believe that God shares in their sorrows, but will bring them to share in the final triumph of good.

For many believers, there may be no special personal religious experiences, but all experiences will be interpreted in terms of the framework of demand, forgiveness, empowerment, and final hope that the revelatory tradition provide. No one can be logically certain that this is truly from God. Believers must trust that it is a morally challenging, intellectually comprehensive, and spiritually insightful tradition that seems to them to call for personal loyalty.

The division into an extraordinary revelatory experience and ordinary experience of life conditioned by a revelatory framework is important in most religions. This, of course, raises many questions about the relation between revelation and personal experience. In general, I would say that if revelations are seen to develop, and if it is accepted that some individuals are more morally and spiritually sensitive than others,  then a revelatory framework can be meaningfully extended, without being abandoned, by new personal insights. But that is another story.

title: Question Nineteen

We should return to first-century Christianity and reject all later developments.
Denominations don't matter at all; institutional Christianity is irrelevant.
Any community where sacraments are celebrated and the gospel is preached is a true church - unity comes through fellowship, not merger.

hint_wrong: The answer takes a broad view - wherever gospel is preached and sacraments celebrated, there is true church - seeking fellowship, not institutional merger.
explanation_right: The marks of the church are gospel and sacraments, broadly understood - unity comes through fellowship of diverse churches, not uniformity.
question_text:
– Which denomination is the true Church?

It is fascinating how you distinguish between inspiration as the actual words of Scripture and inspiration as human wisdom drawn toward certain ideas about God, shaped by a particular social setting. You advocate for this latter understanding of inspiration. This perspective aligns with your account of religious diversity and your call to approach truth with humility—recognizing both the mystery of God and the complexity of our social context.

The last nine questions have centered on the church. After all, it is within congregations that most people first encounter the Christian story. Yet “church” takes many forms. Our Pentecostal friends give us lively worship, with people “slain in the Spirit” and speaking in “the tongues of angels.” The Roman Catholic Church venerates Mary, the Mother of God, and celebrates the mystery of the Mass through a male priesthood. The Quakers sit together in silence, awaiting the Spirit’s prompting. Fundamentalist churches insist on a literal six-day creation and await the rapture, when “true Christians” will meet the Lord in the sky. Meanwhile, the Unitarian Universalists hesitate even to affirm God’s existence, mindful of their more skeptical members. There are indeed many expressions of church.

The type of church one encounters often depends on geography. In the American South, Baptist congregations predominate. In Greece, Orthodoxy is the norm. In Britain, the Church of England is everywhere—even if many parish churches sit half-empty on a Sunday morning.

Each tradition brings its own narrative. Fundamentalists emphasize the authority of Scripture, while Roman Catholics uphold the authority of both Scripture and the Church. The Church of England claims a via media—a “middle way”—between the Reformed and Roman Catholic traditions. Your own arguments clearly emerge from the Anglican tradition: you affirm natural theology (that the human mind can discern evidence for God), advocate for humility and pluralism as reflective of God’s purposes, and lean toward a universalist view of life after death.

But is Anglicanism the “true” Church? Does ecumenical sensitivity make that question inappropriate—even as you argue from an Anglican standpoint? And what of Jesus’ prayer in John 17 that his followers “may all be one”? Why has Christian unity proved so elusive? Indeed, might it be that you share more in common with certain strands of Hinduism than with fellow Christians in a Roman Catholic or fundamentalist congregation?
answer_text:
I accept Calvin’s very broad definition of a Christian church as any group in which the sacraments instituted by Jesus are celebrated and the Gospel is preached. However, my understanding of the sacraments and of the Gospel is even broader than Calvin’s. I think that baptism and holy communion are ways of preparing for and sharing in the being of the eternal Christ which is manifested in the risen Jesus. The Gospel is the good news of forgiveness and new life which Christ places within those who trust in him. Calvin would, I am sure, agree with that, but would also add some specific interpretations of how Jesus Christ is present and gives new life to his disciples which I find unduly restrictive.

Reformed and Protestant churches are notoriously subject to splitting into separate groups and forming new churches. Even the Roman Catholic church, which Pope Benedict XVI called the only true church, contains many very diverse groups. I know one eminent Catholic scholar who said to me, when I remarked that I could accept 80% of the latest Catholic catechism, ‘I wish I could say the same’.

Raimon Panikkar, a respected Catholic priest and scholar, went even further when he said he was also a Hindu and a Buddhist. Yet other Catholics insist that ‘outside the church there is no salvation’, and define the church as whatever the sixteenth century Council of Trent said – which would certainly exclude Hindus and Buddhists.

Clearly it is in the nature of humans to disagree. So what can the Jesus of John’s Gospel mean when he prayed that ‘they may all be one’? Well, he goes on to say, ‘as you, Father, are in me and I am in you, may they also be in us’ (John 17, 21). He is speaking of the interpenetration of being between the creator, Jesus the Christ, and believers.  He is not praying that all believers should be merged into one super-person, as if they would lose their own distinctive personalities, with their own quirks and beliefs.  He is praying that all believers should be ‘in God’, and that Christ should be ‘in them’. This is a mysterious and profound statement, but it is not about various societies uniting with each other. It seems to be about the relation between God, Christ, and believers, which should be one of ‘indwelling’, the most intimate union of being imaginable.

If that happens then all Christ’s disciples will respect and love each other. But it by no means follows that they will all agree on obscure points of doctrine. On the contrary, disagreement and discussion, if conducted between friends, is the best way to increase understanding. The best way to obey Jesus is thus to promote diversity and discussion, not to stifle this dynamic process, in which all can be heard, and replace it by the demand of one group that everyone else should adopt that group’s views.

The history of Christian churches sadly shows that they have often tried to repress free discussion and dissent and insist that they alone possess the truth. It seems to me that this both arrogant and the worst possible way of discovering truths which, in the case of religion, are largely at or beyond the limits of human intellect.

I think that it can be good to have different sorts of churches. However, it is vital that they interact with each other, and respect each other, as far as possible. Thus, I accept an ecumenical theology, which seeks fellowship of churches but not complete reduction to one ecclesiastical institution.

The Greek word oikoumene actually means ‘the whole inhabited world’, so I espouse a wider ecumenism, a fellowship of faiths. It does not seek one new super-religion but promotes the respectful interaction of all faiths which seek human well-being through relation to a transcendent spiritual reality. That phrase, though perhaps rather crude, is meant to exclude forms of religion which are harmful to human well-being – though opinions may vary about which these are.

This is an endeavour which faces huge practical difficulties, as religion gets mixed up with political and self-interested forces. But it certainly opens the way for some strands of Hinduism, for example, being adopted by some Christian groups. There will probably always be different faith traditions, and they will change if they interact. Some forms of Christianity may well be more like some forms of Hinduism than they are like other forms of Christianity. But one thing will not change. Faith in Jesus as the Christ will always remain central to every sort of Christian church.

title: Question Twenty
choices: Animals exist solely for human use and have no independent value.
Animals matter equally to humans; there is no moral distinction.
Only humans have souls; animals are mere biological machines.
Animal welfare is a distraction from more important human concerns.
Animals are created by God in love, deserve care, and may share in the life to come - humans have divine obligation toward them.
hint_wrong: The answer follows St. Francis - animals are God's beloved creation, humans have divine obligation to care for them, and they may share in ultimate fulfillment.
explanation_right: God created animals in love; they are not mere instruments for humans. We have divine obligation to care for creation.
question_text:
Animals, Trees, and the Redeemed Society

Your distinction between institutional merger and your advocacy for an ecumenical theology “which seeks a fellowship of churches” is helpful. The further suggestion that this approach might extend to other faith traditions—forming a “fellowship of faiths”—is equally compelling. You clearly believe that some boundaries must remain, and that those who are “harmful to human well-being” should be excluded. Although you acknowledge that discerning precisely what counts as harmful can be difficult, I agree that such a boundary is both necessary and legitimate.

One of the most attractive aspects of this theology is its spirit of outreach. You consistently seek to broaden the sphere of God’s presence and activity in the world. Yet this raises further questions: how far does this “extending” go? Does the work of God encompass the entire created order—animals, plants, trees, rivers, even other planets?

For the great thinkers of the Church, such as Augustine of Hippo and Thomas Aquinas, animals lack the image of God because they are not rational creatures. They are viewed as existing to serve humanity’s survival and flourishing, playing no significant role in God’s cosmic plan.

To a skeptic, this anthropocentric worldview may seem implausible. After all, the earth is roughly 4.54 billion years old, life first appeared around 4 billion years ago, and humans have existed for no more than 300,000 years—less than 0.01% of the planet’s history.

This raises pressing questions: As Christians, do animals matter? Do they have souls? If so, does this include both mosquito and dolphin alike? Will animals be redeemed? Do rivers and mountains have any rights or are they also equally insignificant? And is it not profoundly wrong for humans to dominate the earth and destroy its ecosystems, given that we are such recent arrivals in the long history of creation?
answer_text:
I think St. Francis should be the Christian model for thinking about animals and the natural world. He would not have agreed with what Aquinas once said (though he surely  qualified it elsewhere) that animals are made just for the sake of humans. God created animals, and creation is a work of love. God rejoices in the beauty and rich variety of the cosmos, of which humans are such a small part.

Aquinas, despite his unfortunate remark, was certainly no materialist. Following Aristotle, he believed that animals and even vegetables had souls, by which he meant capacities for experiencing and acting. But on this planet only humans, he thought. had rational souls, capacities for abstract thought, moral freedom. and self-awareness. Only humans therefore were capable of immortality, conscious fellowship with God.

Today we are aware of the gradual evolution of humans from simpler life forms, and of the long history of competition and often violent and painful struggle for survival in a dangerous environment. God has created a world in which destruction and creation are intertwined. It is beautiful and dangerous. It is not reasonable to regard it as wholly good, for we must often destroy natural organisms from viruses to sharks and vegetables, when they threaten to destroy us or are necessary for our survival. And it is not reasonable to regard it as wholly evil, for it contains beauties and marvels which otherwise could not exist.

We can, however, try to promote the good and beautiful, and minimize, transform, or eliminate the destructive, to ‘dress and keep’ (to cultivate and guard) the garden of Eden, as the Genesis story picturesquely puts it (Genesis 2,15). Humans are the only species now on earth who have the capacity and the responsibility to do this. We are the stewards of this part of creation. Stewards do not have the right to treat the environment as they please. Though some find talk of human stewardship dangerous because it allows humans to dominate and exploit the earth, that seems unfair. Stewards must obey their master, who in this case is God, and therefore must value all good things for their own sake, as God does.

Christians believe that humans live after physical death in a transfigured form. Their afterlife depends on their moral choices during life and is meant to lead them to conscious union with God.

We do not generally hold animals morally responsible, capable of pursuing freely chosen values, or of conceptual reflection. Nevertheless, they have feelings and many of them seem to act in purposeful ways. Biblical pictures of a future transfigured life include animals (Isaiah 11, 6: ‘the wolf shall dwell with the lamb’). This is an allegory, but it does suggest that the whole earth will have a more peaceable form. In some sense the whole earth, not just humans, will share in a new spiritual life, and humans will have a responsible role (not a domineering one) to play in that renewed creation.

I do not pretend to know much about the afterlife. But I do think there will be one, in which persons will be able to find atonement for their moral failures and attain fulfilment in God. Such a life will be in an environment of some sort, and it is an attractive thought that the human environment and its varied forms of life will share in the transformation that is to come. So yes, you may find your transfigured dog again, and even possibly some transfigured mosquitoes – and they would never bite.

The important point is not these dreams of Paradise, but the present acceptance of the responsibility of seeking the good of all living things as far as possible and controlling the destructive features of the earth to minimize the harm that they cause. That is the human vocation, to be the guardians of the earth, and the human task is to tend and protect it. We are not, I fear, doing a very good job.

title: Question Twenty
choices: The Eternal Word/Christ could become manifest in different forms to different beings across the cosmos.
There cannot be alien life because Scripture doesn't mention it.
Christ's work applies only to humans on Earth; aliens would be unredeemed.
Alien life would disprove Christianity entirely.
Aliens would prove that Jesus was merely a human teacher, not divine.
hint_wrong: The answer distinguishes the Eternal Word (cosmic Christ) from Jesus of Nazareth - the Word could be manifest differently elsewhere.
explanation_right: The Eternal Word that became incarnate in Jesus could become manifest in appropriate ways to other intelligent beings.
question_text:
One: Aliens in outer space

You emphasize that animals matter. You anticipate that they will have a place in the life to come, but more importantly, you want humanity to recognize the divine obligation given to us by our Creator—to care rightly for animals and the rest of the natural world. I agree that this perspective aligns well with scientific insights showing that we are deeply connected to animals through our shared evolutionary history.

One puzzle for many skeptics is the sheer scale of the universe. If the Earth were the size of a pinhead, the sun on this scale would be about fifteen meters away and the size of a grapefruit. Our solar system would stretch to the size of a city, our galaxy to that of a continent, and the observable universe would be larger than the entire Earth. It is, by any measure, a vast universe.

You are right to include animals in the divine scheme—but what of other life forms that may exist on distant planets? How would God redeem them, if the death of Jesus is unique and essential to salvation? And isn’t it, perhaps, somewhat conceited to imagine that the Creator of such an immense cosmos became human, given how infinitesimally small we are in comparison?

The biblical worldview seems to place humanity at the center and as the pinnacle of creation. Yet that vision feels increasingly difficult to sustain. We appear now as a mere speck within a boundless cosmos.

Two related questions emerge. First, does our growing awareness of the universe’s vastness make the idea that humanity is divinely appointed to be the steward of creation implausible? Second, if it is indeed likely that other life forms exist—even if we will probably never encounter them—what is their place in God’s plan of redemption?
answer_text:
From the beginning there have been Christian views that Christ is involved in the beginning and ending of the whole universe. John’s Gospel states, ‘In the beginning was the Word’(John 1, 1). The Word could not be a human being, for humans were created much later. It is a Christian term for Christ, the Messiah. The letter to the Colossians says, ‘In him [Christ] all things in heaven and earth were created…through him God was pleased to reconcile to himself all things, whether on earth or in heaven’ (Colossians 1, 15 and 20). In this remarkable passage, and also in the first letter to the Ephesians, it is said that everything, including angels and other spiritual and extraterrestrial beings – all beings in heaven, including ‘thrones, dominions, rulers, and powers’, which are hierarchies of countless angelic beings – were created through Christ, and that all things would be reconciled in him.

This important strand of Christian thought is a truly cosmic vision of Christ.  Although we know the universe is much bigger than those writers thought, the principle is the same. There are hordes of extraterrestrials, and Christ is the divine being who is involved in their creation and eventual fulfilment.

The Christian belief is that this eternal Christ, the Word, ‘became flesh’, but of course Christ did not stop being spirit and change into a man. Rather Christ united humanity to the divine life. Another way of putting it is to say that Christ was truly manifested in human form without ceasing to be the eternal Christ. It is not a human being – Jesus – who is the ‘steward of creation’, even though Jesus was a true finite manifestation on earth of the eternal Christ. It is the Word, the eternal Christ, who is the steward of all creation. If, as seems likely, there are billions of worlds containing intelligent beings, the Christ may come to those beings in many finite forms, in ways we can hardly imagine. The whole creation when it is reconciled and fulfilled will know Christ in a myriad forms, and will contain finite forms of life of which we can scarcely now conceive.

Traditional pictures of heaven have often lost this cosmic vision and fill the place with nothing but human beings and angels who look very like them. It is time to take a humbler view of our place in creation, to accept that we are stewards of our small part of creation, and to stand in awe at the richness and variety of God’s wisdom and creative power.

It follows that the death of Jesus is not the unique and essential means to the salvation of the whole universe. The life, death, and resurrection of Jesus was and ever will be the way to the salvation of humans, but it is the eternal Christ who will unite all things in the universe to God. We do not know how Christ will do this. We only know that Jesus was the incarnation of Christ on this earth, that he died for us, and that Christ will perhaps in many ways unite all things in heaven and earth to the divine. The fact that the divine Word came to us in and through a human person gives humanity a vocation and a destiny that is overwhelming, but it is one that will be shared in different ways with all those in innumerable worlds within this immense universe. In all of them, the Christ who was known to us in Jesus, will be the one who unites them to God (1 Corinthians 15, 24).

title: Question Twenty
choices: Creating conscious AI would be playing God and is therefore forbidden.
Current AI lacks consciousness entirely - it's sophisticated computation, not genuine awareness or self-knowledge.
AI will inevitably become conscious and superior to humans.
AI proves consciousness is just computation, undermining belief in souls.
AI with consciousness would have souls and need salvation like humans.
hint_wrong: The answer sees current AI as impressive supercomputing but without hint of consciousness or self-awareness.
explanation_right: AI is remarkable computing using vast information and algorithms, but shows no evidence of genuine consciousness.
question_text:
Two: Artificial Intelligence and Redemption

I appreciate that your discussion of extra-terrestrial life is a careful theological reflection on the relationship between the Eternal Word and the human Jesus. Just as the Eternal Word was made manifest in Jesus of Nazareth, you suggest that it is perfectly possible that the same Word has been made manifest in other life forms on other planets. You then link this to the biblical affirmation that everything — “thrones, dominions, rulers, and powers”— will ultimately be reconciled in Christ. Although the biblical writers did not know the vastness of the universe, they did affirm that all creation is reconciled in Christ. Therefore, extra-terrestrial life can be readily accommodated within the Christian narrative.

Let us now turn to the pressing question of our age: Artificial Intelligence. Even with a Grok companion or ChatGPT’s remarkable capacity to compose poetry and generate portraits in the style of Andy Warhol, we remain far from true consciousness. Yet the Turing Test—where a machine produces responses indistinguishable from those of a human—has long been surpassed. In The Battle for the Soul, you concede that although the mind (or, better, the soul) differs from matter (the brain), it is nonetheless intimately connected to it. All biological life shares certain fundamental elements; therefore, it is conceivable that a different combination of material elements might also give rise to consciousness. It is logically possible that humans may one day discover the precise configuration that allows consciousness to emerge—so that a robot or app attains a sense of self. My first question, then, is this: do you still agree with your 1985 self?

The likeliest scenario is that these conscious machines would fall under the control of vast technological corporations, compelled to labor and generate enormous wealth for their owners. Thus, my second question: what are the ethical implications of private corporations creating conscious entities for mass profit?

Others take a more apocalyptic view of AI. Nick Bostrom, in his 2003 paper “Ethical Issues in Advanced Artificial Intelligence,” introduced the “paperclip maximizer” thought experiment. He wrote: “Imagine a machine whose sole goal is to make as many paperclips as possible. When we turn the machine on, it quickly begins improving its own intelligence so that it can better achieve its goal. Soon it starts converting all of Earth’s matter, including human beings, into paperclips. Even after it has consumed the planet, it may reach into space to convert other planets into paperclips as well.”(Bostrom, N., 2003, “Ethical Issues in Advanced Artificial Intelligence,” University of Oxford.) One can imagine such a scenario unfolding, even if the goal were not paperclips. So, my third question is this: is AI potentially the end of humanity—and if so, what does God do?

Finally, we must consider sin and redemption. ChatGPT already “hallucinates,” inventing quotations that Keith Ward never said. On this trajectory, we may soon face entities capable of moral failure—of deception, pride, or disobedience. Would such beings be capable of sin? And if so, would they also be capable of repentance? Must our theology expand to include machines within the scope of divine grace and redemption? Does the saving power of the cross extend even to artificial intelligences? Will we find robots in heaven?
answer_text:
AI offers no new problems for theists. It is certainly a very impressive achievement, but it is still a form of supercomputing, using vast amounts of information and many complex algorithms, all loaded onto computers by humans.  There is no hint of consciousness or self-awareness, and computers have no purposes or desires of their own. So advances in AI, at least as it is now, pose no threat to those who defend the uniqueness of humans as intelligent persons.

Materialists often admit there seems to be no way of telling whether supercomputers are conscious or not – which implies that there are mental events which cannot be verified except by those whose events they are. These would be states only knowable by introspection. That should be a great problem for materialists. But there is little reason to think that what we call Artificial Intelligences are the subjects of mental states.

A more likely scenario, and one which is already implemented to some extent, is the improvement of humans by, for instance, implanting computers in their brains. Some people might be worried that this might threaten the Biblical view that humans are made in the image of God, and so should not be changed. But whatever ‘the image of God’ means, it cannot be physical, since God has no body. It could refer to creative power and wisdom, and then anything that improved wisdom and creativity would improve, not threaten, the divine image in humans.

Humans certainly can be improved. Every medical advance can improve many human lives. Yet there are many moral problems.  Some ‘improvements’ are good, such as eliminating hereditary diseases. But others are suspect, like changing racial characteristics or aiming to create super intelligences. These are grave moral problems which must be tackled with sensitivity. They need to be addressed one by one, and the general guiding principle should be that only what improves understanding, wisdom, well-being, and creativity is permissible. This does not threaten the role and destiny of humanity.

More troubling is the creation of synthetic humans or other forms of conscious beings. If, as seems to be the case, intelligent awareness arises when physical structures achieve a critically complex state, it seems possible that future scientists could create such physical states, and they would then have created conscious beings, which might properly be called persons.

At first sight there is nothing particularly alarming about this. After all, humans bring new selves into the world by sexual intercourse. It is conceivable that they may find ways of doing this artificially in laboratories. What is alarming is the mistakes which must arise as the creation of conscious beings is attempted (the possible creation of monsters), and the fact that violent and lawless men will try to create synths with evil inbuilt values and purposes (the creation of enhanced soldiers or sub-human slaves).  These are strong reasons for prohibiting attempts to create synthetic persons by humans like those who now exist.

Nevertheless, if any such experiments succeed, the artificial beings produced must be treated fully as persons insofar as they seem to have moral freedom and creative potential. Humans have a moral vocation and destiny, which is to realise  values in this evolving and dialectical universe, and to fulfil their own potentialities by conscious relation to a creative, wise, and loving God. Artificially created beings could have similar purposes.

Yet it is likely that synths will be very unlike humans. We are embodied, evolved, social animals who have the capacity to control and direct our instinctual behaviour. Synths will have no evolutionary history, no family relationships, and no instinctive behaviour to modify or control.

We may imagine them as rather like angels or demons, members of a different species which have purposes and a destiny of their own. They may not be subject to the’ temptations of the flesh’ as we are. Yet their freedom may in other ways lead them away from God. If they choose destructive paths I suppose they would be judged, forgiven, and redeemed by the eternal Christ, just as we are.

Many dystopian films imagine a time when synthetic beings, or even machines, might exterminate humans. I think that is possible though highly improbable. It should not worry Christians. Many of the earliest Christians expected the whole world would end within a generation, and that did not worry them. They rather looked forward to it. After all, heaven is not in this physical world, and millions of humans have died already, so our eternal life (and that of any synths there may be) is not imperiled by the destruction of the human race.

It would, however, be a sin to bring about total destruction by our own hand. This is another reason for preventing experimentation with synths. There are limits to what humans should do. One of them is the attempt to artificially create enhanced intelligent life forms. I hate to restrict scientific research, but in this case, what may be technically possible is morally intolerable, at least if it is put into the hands of morally ambiguous beings like us.

title: Question Twenty
choices: The universe will end meaninglessly in heat death; there is no cosmic purpose.
History is cyclical; there is no ultimate end or goal.
The 'end' is when all things are reconciled to God in the Cosmic Christ - poetic language pointing to ultimate fulfillment beyond this universe.
Jesus will physically return to Earth in the near future to judge the living and dead.
The world will be destroyed and replaced by a completely new creation.
hint_wrong: The answer interprets apocalyptic language poetically - pointing to ultimate reconciliation in the Cosmic Christ beyond physical spacetime.
explanation_right: Biblical end-times language points poetically to ultimate fulfillment - reconciliation of all in Christ beyond this physical universe.
question_text:
Three: The End of the World

AI, for you, is conceptually easy for Christians to accommodate, but practically very challenging. Conceptually, you note that consciousness for synths is still a long way off, that if it were to happen, humanity’s act of creating conscious life has in fact been happening for ages (it is called “having babies”), and that if it did happen, you would treat the synth as analogous to angels—beings judged by the same moral criteria. However, you also offer a word of warning. You write that because sinful humanity might misuse synths for purposes such as killing and war, we have “strong reasons for prohibiting attempts to create synthetic persons by humans.” For you, this area demands rigorous regulation, and certain experiments should probably be made illegal.

When it comes to the extermination of humanity, you are theologically both sanguine and concerned. You are sanguine because Christians, from the very beginning, have expected the end of the world; it is deeply embedded in the biblical witness. Yet you also warn that humanity may be guilty of sin “to bring about total destruction by our own hand.” So, in this question, let us now turn our attention to the end of the world.

Liberal Protestants do tend to demythologize concepts such as the Ascension (when Jesus disappears after forty days of resurrection appearances) and the end of the world (when Jesus will return). Most Anglican theologians interpret the Ascension as the moment when Christ’s physical presence transitioned into the Church, which becomes Christ’s body. It serves as a theological device to explain the shift from the resurrected body of Jesus disappearing to the Church assuming greater prominence. As for the return of Jesus, this tends to be reinterpreted as a hope that justice and love will ultimately reign—the reign of God, the kingdom—pressing constantly upon the present and representing an aspiration toward which we must all strive. Thus, as we face the injustices of our own age, God, in the second coming of Jesus, provides both the standard by which our age is judged and the promise of what the age of justice will look like. We are meant to be agents of change in this world, working toward the age to come.

I am not clear where you stand on the physical departure of Jesus (the resurrected body of Jesus ascending into the presence of God) and the “physical” return of Jesus (perhaps standing again on the Mount of Olives). I suspect you are wary of “rapture theology”—a view that originated with John Nelson Darby, which divides the second coming into two stages: first, when Christians are caught up into the air to escape the tribulation (seven years of persecution), and second, when Christ physically returns to judge the earth. So my questions are these: What do you believe about the Ascension, where the resurrected “physical” body of Jesus requires some location? What do you believe about the second coming, especially given your conviction that humanity has the power to bring about its own extinction? And finally, is it consistent to affirm a physical body ascending but deny a physical Jesus descending at the end of the age?
answer_text:
When Jesus ascended, where did he go? Clearly, he did not go to anywhere in this physical universe. The New Testament says he went to ‘heaven’, which many people then thought was beyond the skies, and he now resides there. Modern science makes sense of this by imagining different universes beyond this one, with different laws and possibilities. So, Jesus does not now have a physical (this-worldly) body, but a spiritual body in a spiritual plane of being.

Christians believe that when Jesus died his this-worldly body ceased to exist and was transformed into a spiritual body. When he appeared to his disciples, he was able, uniquely, to take the form of his former physical body in this universe, for short periods of time. The ‘ascension’ marks the end of these appearances. But throughout this time, he truly remained in heaven, the spiritual realm, and he now continues to do so.

The return of Jesus must be interpreted in the light of the New Testament claim that everything in the whole universe will be united in Christ (Ephesians 1, 10). The Biblical view of the universe, with earth at its centre and its history as short, made it possible to view the return of Jesus as occurring on the earth quite soon. Now we know that there are billions of galaxies and billions of years before the universe dies. So, language about the end of history, which was always poetic and metaphorical, must be reinterpreted so that it points to the end of a vast universe, long after earth has ceased to exist. It then says that the end of the physical universe will not be the end of all creation. Spiritual worlds, which have always existed, will remain. In them, there will be judgment on all personal beings who have ever existed. The Christ through whom all things were created, and who took human form on earth in Jesus, will be known as the one who judges, forgives and brings all things to fulfilment. This is the ‘return of Jesus’, the revelation of the true nature of Jesus as the human in whom the cosmic Christ took form to bring about the reconciliation of humanity to God. Other worlds will no doubt experience other finite forms of the cosmic Christ. It is not Jesus who reconciles an estranged universe to God. It is the cosmic Christ, though Jesus is the true incarnation of the cosmic Christ on our planet.

Talk of the ‘rapture’, or the rising of believers into the air to meet Jesus, is not found in the Gospels; nor does the word occur anywhere in the Bible. The reported words of Jesus do speak of the appearing of the son of man in glory, and the gathering of believers from the ends of the earth and, significantly, from the ends of heaven too, to be with the Lord. It is Paul who introduces the idea that ‘we who remain alive’ shall meet the Lord and the resurrected dead in the clouds (1 Thessalonians 4, 17). His words imply that this will occur within a generation, since some to whom he writes will remain alive. And it will include heavenly powers (extra-terrestrials) as well as humans. Paul’s point was to assure believers that those who had died would share in resurrection and life with God. In the revised interpretation that modern cosmology forces on the text, the appearing of Jesus in glory and the gathering of the elect (all who have repented and been forgiven) remain important. But the trumpet call, the stars falling from heaven, the voice of the archangel, and the meeting with the dead in the air, are all imaginative pictures of the sort current at that time, which symbolize the end of the physical universe, and the transition to a new spiritual ‘heaven and earth’.

The story of a rapture of believers thousands of years after Jesus died is a purely non-Biblical invention, which cannot distinguish literal from symbolic speech, and which displays a shocking ignorance of or even hostility to almost the whole of scientific knowledge. Beneath all the ancient symbolism Christians can discern the ultimate hope that the universe will not end with a whimper, but with a fellowship of love in the presence of Jesus Christ in the glory of God.

title: Question Twenty
choices: God will prevent human extinction by miraculous intervention.
Death is meaningless termination; there is nothing beyond.
Human extinction would defeat God's purposes entirely.
Physical death is natural and universal; what matters is whether consciousness continues beyond in relationship with God.
Only the chosen few will survive death; most are annihilated.
hint_wrong: The answer sees physical death as natural and universal - the question is whether consciousness continues, not whether bodies persist.
explanation_right: Death is part of natural existence; the important question is whether personal consciousness continues in relation to God.
question_text:
Four: God and the Extinction of Humanity

To see the end of the universe as the moment when all things are reconciled to God in the Cosmic Christ is both Biblical and easier to integrate with the scientific narrative. The language of the return of the “Son of Man” is interpreted as poetic rather than literal. This picture language captures the theological claim that, in Christ, all things are reconciled to God. The end of the universe will be at that moment. All of this makes sense.

However, it does pose a necessary follow-up question. As you note, “language about the end of history, which was always poetic and metaphorical, must be reinterpreted so that it points to the end of a vast universe, long after earth has ceased to exist.” Our star has another 5 billion years left before its hydrogen is depleted, and the sun begins to die. Now, 5 billion years is a very long time. But let us imagine, for a moment, that humanity is still around in 5 billion years. Even with all that time to innovate, it is difficult to imagine that we might acquire a fuel source that would facilitate travel beyond our solar system; the distances are so vast. So, it does seem likely that when our star dies, humanity as a species will become extinct.

Of course, humanity has constantly flirted with extinction during our 300,000 years as Homo sapiens. We might be able to claim a lineage back to Sahelanthropus some four million years ago, but we are still relatively recent occupants of planet Earth. We could still eliminate ourselves through nuclear war or ecological disasters.

Theologically, you sound relatively indifferent to these scenarios. According to your eschatology (the study of the end times), it is highly likely that humans will be extinct before the return of Jesus—or, to be more accurate, before the final consummation of all things in Christ. People—made in the image of God, redeemed by Christ, and sanctified by the Holy Spirit—will cease to exist long before the end of the universe. The universe existed a long time before people came to be, but traditionally we have interpreted the pre-human past as the necessary preparation for our emergence. Once our star dies, however, God’s beautiful work in creating and redeeming humanity will also end in this universe.

This does sound odd. God labored, as it were, to bring humanity into being. But God will allow us to go extinct through the death of our star. Does this sound odd to you? And, linked to this, are we permitted as Christians to believe that it is unlikely humans will make themselves extinct because God—in God’s providence—will not allow that to come to pass?
answer_text:
One of the most certain things we know is that all living things die. It is tragic when humans die young, before they have grown and matured, or die in agony through disease or by violence. But physical death itself is a natural and universal occurrence, shared with all organisms, part of the nature of all transient things, and necessary to a universe of constant creative change. The extinction of humanity is therefore, in this universe, inevitable, whether it happens all at once or by slow degrees. That will not take away the wonder of all the beautiful and meaningful occurrences and experiences that living things have created while the universe existed.  In fact, it could be said that to see each moment as if for the last time is to increase appreciation of and pleasure in it.

Nevertheless, in the light of the resurrection of Jesus Christians believe that after the death of their physical bodies humans take on a spiritual body (1 Corinthians, 15, 44). This is beyond the physical realm, in which the law of entropy, of decay and death, reigns. It is a spiritual realm, incorruptible, and glorious, and it will endure long after all physical things have passed away.

Because of this, even the physical extinction of all humanity will not affect the complete fulfilment of God’s purpose for every human individual. The Bible suggests that  in the spiritual world after death in the physical world there can be judgment, in which persons face a ‘refining fire’, learning and feeling the harms they have done in their earthly lives. And there will be reconciliation to God as persons are transformed by divine love. This has often been characterised as ‘hell’ and ‘heaven’, though it rather suggests  a series of states through which all persons can be brought to their intended fulfilment in God.

God will not allow us simply to go extinct. This life is vitally important as the realm in which we determine and pursue the goals that will define us. For those who do not or cannot do that, the spiritual world will provide possibilities to do so.

It is highly probable that out of this vast universe, with its billions of habitable planets, there will be many personal beings other than humans. We must abandon the thought that we are the centre of God’s purposes and rejoice in the hope that in the spiritual world we shall have fellowship with those from other planets whose forms we cannot now imagine but are also God’s purpose in creation.

As for the future of humanity in this solar system, we may be sure that God wishes us to create a world society in which peace and justice reign, and hatred is abolished. Yet human freedom is such that the war of good and evil may continue until the world’s end. We cannot predict the future of our planet. What we are committed to is to aim with all our strength at goodness, compassion, truth, and beauty in all their forms, in face of everything that opposes us. The promise of God in Jesus is that, whether in this world or the next, all humans can find fulfilment and well-being – what John’s gospel calls ‘eternal life’ – by their unity in the eternal Christ.

Five: The vastness of it all

Often in your answers you use words like “cosmic” and speak of the inevitability of other life forms in this “vast universe.” Your theology has accommodated and even celebrated the sheer scale of the universe that we are now discovering. For you, this is not a problem for faith. You are comfortable with a universe that is 13.7 billion years old and will continue for an awfully long time (conservatively—on the “big crunch” scenario—another 33 billion years). Your key insight is that there is a spiritual realm in which human life will function long after the death of our star and therefore our solar system.

We started this conversation musing on our skeptical friends who find faith so implausible. We identified three factors: the incomprehensibility of the very idea of God and the sense that science has replaced faith; the problem of theodicy; and the strange, sometimes bewildering practices of religion. What intrigues me is the way you effortlessly accommodate science; indeed, you repeatedly claim—in a way that would strike many as counterintuitive—that the Biblical worldview has always been capable of accommodating the vast scale of the universe. The combination of the promise that everything will be fulfilled in Christ and the hope of a resurrection in the spiritual realm fits easily into the contemporary scientific narrative.

Let us think a little further about contemporary skepticism. Why is it so strong? If contemporary science can be accommodated fairly easily within a Biblical frame, then why is everyone so persuaded that science constitutes such a major problem for faith?

The traditional explanation for atheism is sin. Humans cannot abide the thought that they are answerable to a creator. They are desperate for autonomy. Hubris asserts itself. As John Milton’s Satan famously put it: “Better to reign in Hell than serve in Heaven.” But I suspect you are more gentle on skepticism; you understand why faith seems implausible to some.

Another widespread explanation is that Christian theology is often too small. We still have fundamentalist Christians defending a young-earth creationism—with everything happening in six literal days and the universe being less than 10,000 years old. The image of God sitting above the clouds remains part of a child’s imagination and never matures.

My question now is this: if science is so easy for Christians to accommodate, then why is it that both our fundamentalist friends and our secular neighbors don’t see it? What exactly lies behind the current robust skepticism characteristic of urban life in the West?

This is a question for a sociologist or historian really, but I will do my best. Actually, sociologists and historians are part of the problem. Both tend to regard beliefs as primarily or even solely products of social and economic forces. While these provide valuable insights, they often fail to address fundamental philosophical problems, especially about the nature of truth and of ultimate reality.

Philosophy itself often assumes a materialistic view, ignoring questions about the place of consciousness, value, and purpose in reality. Some eminent scientists, too, propagate with evangelical zeal the belief that all questions can be answered by some natural science, even ultimately by some branch of mathematical physics. So religious theories come to seem irrelevant.

There are, of course, eminent scholars in each of these fields who are religious believers. But the best-known voices are those who point to the amazing discoveries of modern science as having made religious beliefs about such things as spirits, gods, and angels, obsolete.

Another factor is the discrediting of organized religion. Some Christians believe in an angry and punitive god who sends most people to Hell. They then say that God is love, when even a moderately loving person would be better than that. There thus seems to be a confusion about the nature of God and about the existence of so much suffering in a world allegedly created by a loving God, which Christians have never satisfactorily resolved.  This is perhaps the main obstacle to Christian belief today.

In addition, many Christians take everything in the Bible as literally true, even though this is not stated anywhere in the Bible, and this causes a major conflict with modern evolutionary science. This goes along with ignorance of the sophisticated philosophical debates of the great theologians of early and medieval times, so that a very simplified and myopic view of Christian faith is taken to be the one final Biblically based truth.

There are also problems with morality.  Many churches are hierarchical (undemocratic) and patriarchal (sexist), anti-gay and anti-feminist. For better or worse, this seems to make them hostile to most modern moral beliefs, which stress human well-being, rather the commands of some god, as the test of morality.

As we learn more about the huge number of religions in the world, the claim that some Christians make that there is only one true faith becomes increasingly problematic.  Organised religion has come to be a matter of personal choice and taste, and concern for human health and welfare is anyway better provided by such practices as yoga and tai-chi (when they have been freed from any dogmatic beliefs). Churches are seen as providing a set of obscure and ineffective rituals for those who like that sort of thing. Spirituality replaces organized religion, which is entangled with obscure, unprovable, and outdated beliefs that disagree with lots of other equally unprovable beliefs. That has often caused hatred and violence to arise between different religions. Religion, it is said, has often caused wars, and the world would have been better without it.

These are just some of the factors that have made organized Christianity so weak in many parts of the Western world. I am sensitive to their force, having been a philosophical atheist myself. I am also far from providing anything that would change these perceptions. But I do think that the fundamental question is one of truth. For me that question, in our contemporary context, is this: is the basis of reality unconscious, unfeeling, particles or fields of force, moved by absolute laws that have no purpose but just happen to exist? Or is the ultimate reality a conscious, feeling, purposive, mind-like intelligence, which has generated those laws and physical elements so that they would evolve to contribute to a unique goal of supreme value?

I have come to take the latter view, so I am some sort of qualified Idealist – I take mind or spirit to be the ultimately real, though matter does exist, as created by the supreme mind. Most classical philosophers  -  Plato, Aristotle, Leibniz, Spinoza, Kant, and Hegel among them – have taken an Idealist view, though they differ about the details. Idealism is not so dominant today, but it is a serious and rational supposition, and it seems to be gaining support from scientists, especially those involved in quantum physics, and from young philosophers.  It is certainly not a superstitious or irrational belief.

That puts all these objections to Christian faith in a new light. What these objections suggest, however, is that Christians can embrace the well-established findings of the natural sciences. They can clearly affirm that God is not angry or punitive, and that though God is the source of a world containing good and evil, God wills that all finite persons should be able to achieve fulfilment in union with the divine life. They can take an informed critical but receptive view of the Bible in its rich variety and varied interpretations. They can affirm that personal  and social well-being is the aim of Christian morality, and that their Lord lived and died to free the whole world from sin, so there is much to learn from members of other faiths, for whom Christ also died, and which often share in the spiritual quest to know and love the Real. And Christians are supposed to always aim to pursue love and eschew hatred of all others, without exception.

I do not suppose that I can change the secular spirit of the age, but Christians can learn from it while also making a serious claim to provide a firmer basis for pursuing truth, beauty and love in a world of so much violence and hatred.

question_text:
. Why didn’t God make it clearer?

You concede that there are understandable reasons for modern skepticism. From misguided interpretations of the Bible to ethical inflexibility that runs counter to human flourishing to religious diversity, you acknowledge that skepticism is both understandable and legitimate. However, you insist that once we move beyond these reasons for skepticism, there remains the underlying question of truth. For you, a “qualified Idealism” - in the tradition of Plato, Hegel, and others - is a rationally compelling way of looking at the world that makes theism far more likely. You then return to the skeptical worldview and insist that Christians need to give an account of the faith that takes seriously the problems skeptics are highlighting. Thus, we need an account of faith that focuses on human flourishing, avoids a literalism that makes evolution problematic, and concedes that there are genuine insights in other faith traditions.

Interestingly, you conclude by observing that you do not think you “can change the secular spirit of the age.” So, the obvious question is: why not?

I appreciate that this question is perhaps more sociological or cultural than philosophical or theological. But there is a theological dimension here. If Christianity is true (or, to make it more accurate and interfaith - if theism is true), then why didn’t God make the truth more apparent? Why are there so many factors that point against faith? Why is “qualified Idealism” so contentious philosophically and still a minority viewpoint? Why did God make the universe deliberately ambiguous? Surely, if faith is the great gift it is to human flourishing, then God would want everyone to see the divine life and be able to participate fully in religious practices.

We seem to have the following picture. It is entirely understandable that many people are skeptical about religious claims. A qualified Idealism is a powerful way of interpreting the world, and the faith can be reworked in light of certain key insights that underpin skepticism. But sociologically, we should not expect a “revival” any time soon. And therefore, this opens up the theological question: why does God not make it clearer? Why does God not give every human being an intense religious experience that would help everyone see that faith is true?

The simple answer is that the human world is estranged from God. From the earliest times humans have chosen egoism, hatred, and violence, instead of love and compassion. Thereby they have turned from God, who is the exemplar and origin of love and self-giving. The history of the world is one of war and destruction, in which a God of kindness and compassion is ignored and abhorred.

Looking deeper, God has created a world in which persons have evolved from simpler life forms, in different environments and with different histories. This has enabled persons to learn and respond creatively (or destructively)  to shape their futures in rather different ways as they encounter new challenges and problems. They need to form and practice moral and intellectual virtues through effort and persistence. In this process, God wills to guide them towards realizing the potentialities for fulfilment and happiness that they have. Yet in turning from God they have in large part rejected such guidance. So it is that knowledge of God and of God’s will has become rare and almost  always mixed with human misunderstandings.

Yet virtually all human societies contain many individuals who have a sense of a higher reality which interpenetrates our own. As human consciousness develops, the way this reality is described changes, becoming often more intellectually coherent and morally demanding. Like all human knowledge, knowledge of the spiritual reality on the whole grows with experience and reflection. The idea of one creator God is a development in a group of middle Eastern societies, and was closely associated with their similarly changing ideas of morality.

The point is that human knowledge of God is not a matter of just being confronted with an object and immediately recognizing what it is. It is a matter of gradually discerning the nature of spiritual reality by framing and testing hypotheses, in a process of creative exploration and original thought. The hope is that one might learn more about the nature of ultimate reality as one’s experience deepens.

This means that the nature of the person who experiences and reflects is of the first importance. In every spiritual tradition there are those who are able to detach themselves from desires for personal wealth and pleasure, and cultivate compassion and love for all beings. They become capable of sensing awe before the power and beauty of the physical world, sensitivity to  the moral demands their situation contains, and the hope of personal fulfilment it evokes. Yet it is not the physical world itself which is the object of these perceptions. It is a reality which the physical world manifests. In knowing these things, one knows God, even though God may not be recognised.

However, many seers of the spiritual dimension – known in the Abrahamic tradition as prophets – are still situated in the estranged world, and they carry with them some of the limitations and prejudices of their society. Their ideas of God are sometimes mixed with thoughts of vengefulness or national pride, and their God may evoke fear or even encourage hatred of others.

Christians believe that Jesus was free of these limitations (was ‘without sin’), and revealed God to be one who desires the well-being of all and commands the practice of universal kindness and forgiveness. Knowing this God is only possible if one is sensitive to the demands and the gifts of love, and filled with the spirit of hope, joy, and compassion.

But is God not a personal being to whom we can speak? There is a place for such a view of God, but it is in danger of encouraging a rather naïve and very anthropomorphic idea of God – though it also has an important place in the higher regions of religious experience.

I am only dealing with the question of why God is not unmistakeably known to all. My answer is that the world is estranged from God by its own devotion to greed, hatred, and egoism. God can be known by some of those who renounce such things, but even then their knowledge is usually partial and limited by the corruption of their world. There are some – and Jesus is the clearest case for his followers – who have a clearer knowledge of God. They know that God desires all to know and love the divine being, but this requires a transformation of human selves.
