question_text:
Questions people ask: What about ghosts?

I find your argument compelling. There are two features to your response. The first is the observation that all knowing is gradual and a matter of discernment. Even scientific knowing - especially when it involves interpreting data as it is experienced - takes time and is heavily shaped by cultural context. The second feature is the insistence that sin is real (interestingly, you tend to avoid the word sin): humanity consistently opts for selfishness over compassion. As a result, knowledge of the divine becomes very difficult. Even those prophets who attain a partial knowledge of the divine often introduce their own distortions because of their propensities toward selfishness, resulting in a much more limited understanding of God. Jesus is the one who saw God most clearly because Jesus was full of compassion. All of this makes sense.

In this book, we have examined the nature of God, the reasons for belief, the complexity of ethics, and the nature of the Church (and with it, relations with the world, animals, AI, aliens, and so on). In the next two sections, the questions will focus on miscellaneous topics that do not quite fit into the above categories. In the final section, the questions will focus on you and where you are after a lifetime of witnessing to the faith.

So, miscellaneous question number one. There is an extraordinarily high percentage of people who believe in the paranormal, and in ghosts in particular. The paranormal is an umbrella term that includes ghosts and hauntings, but also extrasensory perception, telepathy, clairvoyance, psychic or spiritual healing, reincarnation, astrology, and even demons and angels. Ghosts are understood as the disembodied spirits of the dead, who can haunt a place and might appear, but who always provide some presence of the dead in our world.

In Britain, Atomik Research reported in 2021 that 55% of British people have encountered a ghost, and a further 17% have experienced something mysterious that might be a ghost. More generally, 76% of British people believe in some form of paranormal activity. In the United States, CivicScience reported in 2024 that 41% of Americans believe in God, while 64% believe in the paranormal.

It is also striking that a 2025 YouGov survey reported that just 28% of the British population believes in God. In the UK, then, belief in the paranormal and in ghosts is more prevalent than belief in God, which suggests that Britain is not a population of consistent materialists.

My question, however, is this: can a Christian incorporate ghosts into a Christian schema? Traditionally, Christians believe that once you cross over, you cannot return. This view is often deduced from the parable of Lazarus and the rich man in Luke 16, where the rich man’s request to return and warn his brothers is not permitted. Yet C. S. Lewis, in The Great Divorce, imagines some of the souls in “hell” occasionally making journeys to earth to be present with those who are still living. So where do you stand on ghosts, and on the paranormal more generally?

RESPONSE

The parable of  Lazarus and the rich man  in Luke (chapter 16, verses 19 – 31) is very interesting. If we take it seriously it seems that humans live after their physical deaths, and that they converse and think. They do not exist anywhere in the physical world, so there is another realm of being where humans face the consequences of their earthly actions, and they do not just sleep until the resurrection, as some other passages in the New Testament seem to suggest.

The place where they are is Hades (the realm of the dead), that is not Hell, as some theologians later misleadingly called it.  Lazarus is  comforted ‘in Abraham’s bosom’, which implies that he lived among mainly Jewish dead and was able to recognize them. The rich man is tormented by flames (this is a common Jewish metaphor for torment, but what that is probably depends on the individual). He can see Abraham ‘from afar’, and talk with him (so they are in  the same place, Hades ) but a great chasm lies between them, preventing passage from one area to the other.

The rich man (who is not called Dives!) asks Abraham if he will send messengers to earth ( which implies that such a thing is possible), but Abraham says that it would be a waste of time (he does not explicitly forbid it for everyone).There is no hint about how long the rich man is to be tormented, but a general Jewish view,  and ordinary human compassion agrees,  is that afterlife punishments, though real, would be finite. Certainly, Jesus’ teaching that one should forgive without limit, and the parable  of the Prodigal Son, imply that God will forgive all who repent. So if the rich man repents, the chasm will surely be bridged. After all, Abraham calls the rich man ‘son’ or ‘child’, and no father would allow his child to suffer for ever.

But you ask about ghosts and the paranormal,  I suppose that if mind is prior to and expressed in matter, and if the dead continue to exist as individuals, it is possible that the dead could appear on earth and that mental communication (telepathy)could occur.  Whether they do is a question of fact.

Christians generally believe that Jesus was a faith healer, that he performed many miracles, showing the power of mind over matter,  and that he had privileged knowledge of God, the afterlife, of judgment and redemption. He also preached to the dead (1 Peter, 3, 19), even to the  ‘ spirits in prison’, who had rejected God in the days of Noah – and who were seemingly still under punishment, though no longer as severe as whatever being in the flames implies. The writer expands on this theme by writing that Jesus preached the gospel to all the dead, so that ‘they might be judged according to men in the flesh, but live according to God in the spirit’ (1 Peter, chapter 4, verse 6 – an echo of Paul’s view that in Adam all die, but in Christ all are made alive - 1 Corinthians, 15, 22).

These passages entail that those who die can hear the words of Jesus and be saved, which is good news indeed. It disproves the belief of some Christians that repentance after death is not possible.

Of course Jesus, living in ‘heaven’, crossed the chasm between the living and the dead, as did Elijah and Moses. and according to Matthew 27, 52 and 53, many of the dead. It seems, then, that Christians are committed to believing that some paranormal events have occurred, and that some of the dead have appeared on earth.

The problem is that there is a great deal of deception, trickery, and illusion, about such things. Some of them, in forms of occultism and Satanism, are evil and dangerous. In view of that, one should be very suspicious of claims  about paranormal occurrences. Despite that, the prevalence of paranormal occurrences shows that most people are not materialists. But safeguards are needed against dangerous, frightening, or false claims.

Christian faith in Jesus as the human image of God, and the long tradition of theological reflection and personal experiences, provides such safeguards. Intellectually, there is the provision of a strong, coherent, philosophical worldview. Ethically, the guidance of Jesus’ teaching and example establishes the primacy of love for all beings. And emotionally, devotion to Christ provides the wholly adequate and ideal object of human reverence.

I conclude that there are and have been ghosts and many paranormal phenomena. If tested by the  intellectual, ethical, and emotional criteria provided by Christian faith in a loving,  self-sacrificing, incarnate,  and redemptive God, they are not to be feared. They can often strengthen belief in the existence of spiritual reality, and may lead to commitment to a rational, moral, and supremely perfect basis for existence, which is what Jesus Christ proclaims.

The rich man (who is not called Dives!) asks Abraham if he will send messengers to earth ( which implies that such a thing is possible), but Abraham says that it would be a waste of time (he does not explicitly forbid it for everyone).There is no hint about how long the rich man is to be tormented, but a general Jewish view,  and ordinary human compassion agrees,  is that afterlife punishments, though real, would be finite. Certainly, Jesus’ teaching that one should forgive without limit, and the parable  of the Prodigal Son, imply that God will forgive all who repent. So if the rich man repents, the chasm will surely be bridged. After all, Abraham calls the rich man ‘son’ or ‘child’, and no father would allow his child to suffer for ever.

But you ask about ghosts and the paranormal,  I suppose that if mind is prior to and expressed in matter, and if the dead continue to exist as individuals, it is possible that the dead could appear on earth and that mental communication (telepathy)could occur.  Whether they do is a question of fact.

Christians generally believe that Jesus was a faith healer, that he performed many miracles, showing the power of mind over matter,  and that he had privileged knowledge of God, the afterlife, of judgment and redemption. He also preached to the dead (1 Peter, 3, 19), even to the ‘ spirits in prison’, who had rejected God in the days of Noah – and who were seemingly still under punishment, though no longer as severe as whatever being in the flames implies. The writer expands on this theme by writing that Jesus preached the gospel to all the dead, so that ‘they might be judged according to men in the flesh, but live according to God in the spirit’ (1 Peter, chapter 4, verse 6 – an echo of Paul’s view that in Adam all die, but in Christ all are made alive - 1 Corinthians, 15, 22).

These passages entail that those who die can hear the words of Jesus and be saved, which is good news indeed. It disproves the belief of some Christians that repentance after death is not possible.

Of course, Jesus, living in ‘heaven’, crossed the chasm between the living and the dead, as did Elijah and Moses. and according to Matthew 27, 52 and 53, many of the dead. It seems, then, that Christians are committed to believing that some paranormal events have occurred, and that some of the dead have appeared on earth.

The problem is that there is a great deal of deception, trickery, and illusion, about such things. Some of them, in forms of occultism and Satanism, are evil and dangerous. In view of that, one should be very suspicious of claims about paranormal occurrences. Despite that, the prevalence of paranormal occurrences shows that most people are not materialists. But safeguards are needed against dangerous, frightening, or false claims.

Christian faith in Jesus as the human image of God, and the long tradition of theological reflection and personal experiences, provides such safeguards. Intellectually, there is the provision of a strong, coherent, philosophical worldview. Ethically, the guidance of Jesus’ teaching and example establishes the primacy of love for all beings. And emotionally, devotion to Christ provides the wholly adequate and ideal object of human reverence.

I conclude that there are and have been ghosts and many paranormal phenomena. If tested by the  intellectual, ethical, and emotional criteria provided by Christian faith in a loving,  self-sacrificing, incarnate,  and redemptive God, they are not to be feared. They can often strengthen belief in the existence of spiritual reality, and may lead to commitment to a rational, moral, and supremely perfect basis for existence, which is what Jesus Christ proclaims.

question_text:
Questions People Ask: what about the devil and demons?

Through a mixture of reflection on an authority (namely the Bible) and general theological principles (for example, the primacy of love), you determine that knowledge of - and even movement to and from - the realm of the dead (Hades) is possible. However, you caution that there are dangers involved, including deception by fraudulent individuals and engagement with the occult.

This opens the door to another question people often us, namely, Satan and demons. What exactly do you mean when you write, “Some of them, in forms of occultism and Satanism, are evil and dangerous”? The narrative of Satan as a fallen angel—who becomes identified with the serpent in Eden and leads an army of demons—is deeply entrenched both in the popular imagination and in the theology of certain major theologians, such as Thomas Aquinas.

The problems with this narrative are well known. The biblical record begins with Satan as the accuser, appearing in the book of Job as part of the heavenly court and given permission to test Job. This seems a long way from the Satan of the tradition who is in resolute opposition to God. The Satan of the tradition carries hints of cosmic dualism—two equal and opposing supreme forces (God and Satan) battling over the world—which is clearly incompatible with the Christian affirmation of monotheism. It also intensifies the problem of theodicy: why would God tolerate such a destructive presence within creation?

The temptation is to suggest that Christians should reinterpret Satan into a symbol for intense evil. One complication with this option is that it is clear that Jesus believed in the reality of demons. Demons are a pervasive theme in the Gospels. You write: “Christians generally believe that Jesus was a faith healer, that he performed many miracles, showing the power of mind over matter, and that he had privileged knowledge of God, the afterlife, of judgment and redemption.” If Jesus had privileged knowledge of God and the afterlife, then surely we must concede that demons are real.

The question, then, is this: do you believe in the Devil and demons? If you do, what can they do? And if you do not, are you comfortable saying that Jesus got this wrong?

RESPONSE

Theologians are quite used to regarding most Biblical descriptions of God as symbolic or metaphorical. For instance, if God is described as walking in the garden of Eden, this is easily taken to be not literally true, but as referring metaphorically to the divine presence. As is often said, God is not an object or person one might come across in a garden or anywhere else. God is the origin of all finite beings.

It is likely to be similar with talk of Satan. In the Bible the term Satan and its many cognates is used in many senses. Sometimes it refers to a servant of God whose job is to test or tempt people. Sometimes it seems to refer to a spiritual entity who rules the nations and opposes God’s purposes. Sometimes it refers to the evil inclinations which are parts of human nature.  There are many other strands of thought, but they all associate Satan with evil or opposition to God’s will.

God is seen as supreme truth, beauty, and love, whereas Satan represents the opposing powers of falsehood (the ‘father of lies’), chaos and disorder, and hatred and warfare. Nearly all religions have some figure who represents these powers, and there is wide agreement that such powers exist, that they oppose any cosmic purposes of goodness, and that they will in the end be defeated, not by violence but by love.

Christians generally believe that God is the only origin of all things. In God all possibles exist, and many of them involve suffering. There are many different views about why God should create evil, but I think the only satisfactory explanation is that God could not help it. That is, any world God created would contain the real possibility of evil and suffering. I cannot believe that God would positively choose to create evil, but I can imagine that all possibles will by their nature press towards realisation. Negative possibilities seem to be parasitic on positives, so there could not be a world of pure negativity. What God may choose to do is to fashion a cosmos of ordered  values out of this primordial reservoir of beings. In this process, conscious intelligent beings could play an important part, as fellow workers with God in ordering the cosmos towards new forms of goodness. But they may also derail God’s purposes by failing to understand or contribute to the general good.

For an Idealist, there could exist angels and demons, conscious and intelligent entities other than human, and there could exist a Satan, one very powerful angel who opposed God’s purposes. But there already are plenty of humans who are satanic, and commit the most appalling evil acts, which cause suffering to millions of people and animals. We do not need a Satan to account for this. Human lust and aggression, rooted in the struggle for survival in evolution, will do so very well. In Biblical times, there was no idea of evolution, and so it seemed necessary to have Satan and demons to account for evil in an allegedly good creation. Yet there never developed a coherent idea of Satan and of how he came to exist. It looks as if Satan and demons are parts of an explanation for evil which is, though possible, now obsolete and unnecessary.

There is a specific problem for Christians, however. Jesus carried out many exorcisms and even spoke with demons, so many Christians feel compelled to accept the existence of demons. Yet modern medicine no longer accepts that illnesses are caused by demons. I accept the amazing advances of modern medicine, and so demons and exorcisms are not part of my understanding of the world. How then can I understand what the New Testament says about Jesus’ exorcisms?

I will have to say that the Bible is mistaken in some of its beliefs about the world. When you think about it, however, that is hardly surprising. People at that time knew nothing about galaxies or electrons or viruses. Human knowledge has changed and increased enormously since then. The claim sometimes made that the Bible is inerrant cannot be upheld, because Biblical knowledge of the world was largely inaccurate.  Passages about Jesus’ conversations with demons are stories to show Jesus’ power over disease and illness.

Looking at similar stories told about great saints and heroes in cultures throughout the world, it becomes clear that stories about them grow more and more amazing as time goes by.  It is not surprising that the same thing should happen with Jesus. So it is likely that Jesus did have remarkable powers of healing and wisdom, which have been exaggerated over time.

Jesus himself is represented as believing in demons and exorcism, and if so he too was mistaken about some things. He is therefore not omniscient or infallible. This too is not surprising, if he was truly human. He could, for instance,  have had an extraordinary sense of union with God and of God’s purposes, without knowing the theory of special relativity. He could have been taught about demons, and practiced exorcism, even though the underlying theoretical framework about such actions  was mistaken.

My conclusion is that there could be Satan and demons. Many Christians will believe, on the authority of Scripture, that there are. But their role will today be very different than it was believed to be in New Testament times. Demons will not be the causes of all illnesses, and Satan will not be the cause or incitor of all suffering in the world – humans can do that very well on their own. So Satan is often seen as a personification of  the evil inclinations of human  nature. This is a common Jewish view, and that is the view that appeals to me. Indeed, I would go further and say that most Christians should focus on the good news of new life in Christ, and avoid negative thoughts about Satan and attempts to contact alleged demons. I am comfortable with saying that Jesus, if he held a more substantive view of Satan as an individual agent (which I doubt), was mistaken. He might have learned such a view in his culture, but his healing ministry could  have operated without it,  and it did not otherwise play an important role in his teaching.

It is difficult for some people to accept that human knowledge of the cosmos has changed hugely since the Biblical books were written. The earth is no longer seen as the centre of the universe, and heaven is not to be found above the sky. Unless we ignore modern science, and refuse such things as medical care and mobile phones, we have to accept that the Biblical writers were mistaken in many of their beliefs about physical nature. It seems probable that the idea of Satan and demons causing illnesses and earthquakes is part of an outmoded worldview.

Yet though our knowledge of the physical universe has changed, the idea that there is a spiritual reality underlying the physical, and that this reality is disclosed in and through exceptional individuals, remains hauntingly powerful. Christians are those who find in Jesus their window into the spiritual dimension.  Whatever we think of Satan, it is in the living Christ that his followers can find a new quality of life, and that is the ultimate test of truth in the spiritual realm.

question_text:
Nine: Questions People Ask: Heaven

It was interesting to watch you work through the topic of Satan. You acknowledge the different accounts of Satan within the biblical witness, and you also recognize that Jesus appears to have believed in demons and to have performed exorcisms. However, you argue that the human capacity for wickedness does not require an actual “Satan” - a personal source of evil - to exist. We are quite capable of extraordinary evil on our own. You also note that many phenomena once explained as demon possession are now understood, thanks to science, in different and more accurate ways. Thus, while the existence of Satan is possible, you suggest that it is unlikely. And if Jesus did believe in Satan, then Jesus was, in that respect, mistaken.

I confess that I am equally tormented by this topic. On the authority of Jesus - who comes from the spiritual realm to reveal the spiritual realm - I feel obligated to acknowledge an objective source of evil, with related entities in the spiritual realm. But then I want to stop. The dangers of preoccupation with such matters are real.

Remaining within the spiritual realm, I want to ask an age-old question that every Christian eventually faces: What is heaven like? When this question is asked in this country, people tend to want to know whether they will recognize their loved ones, whether their dog will be there, and whether they will be able to play golf and still have long conversations with their friends. Does heaven, in some ways, resemble earth? Everyone hopes that it will be free from pain, and most people assume that it is meant to last forever. But what, exactly, should we expect?

The philosopher Bernard Williams famously worried that an eternity of time would inevitably give rise to boredom. He makes imaginative use of the fictional character Elina Makropulos, who discovers that after 342 years her life has become joyless and cold, and that she has no interest in any further extension of it.

So the question people continue to ask is this: what is heaven like, and how are we to understand an eternity of time in which we are able to find enough meaning, purpose, and activity to sustain us?
